While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.
A brahmin asks whether the person who acts is the same or different to the person who receives the result. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
The brahmin Jāṇussoṇi asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
A brahmin cosmologist asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.
A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.

A mendicant should thoroughly investigate the causes of suffering in accordance with dependent origination. If someone who still has ignorance makes a choice, their consciousness fares on to a suitable state of existence. But one who has eradicated ignorance is detached and is not reborn anywhere.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a bonfire.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a sapling.
The mental and physical organism is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
Consciousness is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
When Ānanda suggests that dependent origination is simple, the Buddha rebukes him. The opening of this is similar to DN 15 Mahānidāna.

An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind, which jumps about like a monkey.

An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind. But a noble disciple reflects on dependent origination.
The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. He illustrates them with a series of powerful and horrifying similes.
The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness, showing how they lead to suffering according to dependent origination.
The Buddha tells the story of how his awakening came about through investigation into dependent origination. He compares it to a man discovering and ancient city, lost and overgrown with weeds.
The right way to investigate inside oneself is to see how suffering is created by craving and attachment, stimulated by pleasant experiences.
Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the factors of dependent origination are created by oneself, another, both, or by chance.

Venerable Saviṭṭha questions Venerable Musīla about his attainments, and concludes he is an arahant. But Venerable Nārada offers an explanation showing that it is possible to see the Dhamma without having fully realized arahantship.
Like rivers flowing to the ocean, the factors of dependent origination lead to suffering.

The wanderer Susı̄ma fraudulently enters the Sangha so that the wanderers can learn the secret to the Buddha’s fame and success. Hearing that some mendicants claimed to be perfected, Susīma approaches and asks them if they have developed psychic powers or the formless states, to which they say no. Perplexed, he asks the Buddha, who explains that awakening follows insight into the principles of impermanence and causality. Eventually Susı̄ma confesses his misdeed.
One who does not understand aging and death is no true ascetic.

sc_eng_sutta: A Set of Ten on Rebirth, Etc.
sc_blurb: One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination is no true ascetic.
One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination should seek a teacher.

sc_eng_sutta: Sets of Eleven on Training, Etc.

sc_blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like the dirt under a fingernail.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in a massive dam; what remains is like a few drops on a blade of grass.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.
For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Sineru, king of mountains; what remains is like seven bits of gravel
The senses function due to the various different elements of sense experience, namely, the internal sense organ, the external sense stimulus, and consciousness.
The diverse internal elements of sense experience give rise to diverse contacts.
It is not the case that diverse contacts give rise to the diverse elements of sense experience.
Diverse contacts give rise to diverse feelings.
It is not the case that diverse feelings give rise to diverse contacts.
The senses function due to the various different external elements of sense experience, namely, the various sense stimuli.
The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests.
It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.
The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions.
It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.

A rare group of seven elements: light, beauty, the four formless states, and the attainment of cessation. Each of these is known due to the negation of something: light vs. darkness, beauty vs. ugliness, and so on.
Thoughts of sensuality, ill-will, and cruelty arise due to a series of causes.
When unenlightened people have the view that certain people are Buddhas, this is due to ignorance.
People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together.
The Buddha points out that each of the great disciples has a retinue of students of a similar character. And the monks in Devadattas’s retinue all have evil wishes.
People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together. Illustrated with similes and verses.
The faithless and those of other bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
The four material elements of earth, water, heat, and air. Note that “air” is close in meaning to “wind”.
Before his awakening the Buddha saw the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements.
The Buddha set out to discover the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements, and found it.
Each of the three aspects of the four material elements performs its own function. Gratification stimulates desire; drawbacks lead to disillusionment, while escape opens the possibility of freedom.
If the material elements were solely painful, beings would not get attached. If they were solely pleasurable, it would be impossible to become detached.
When you seek pleasure in the material elements, you seek pleasure in suffering.
The arising of the material elements is the arising of suffering.
One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
Transmigration is endless, like the grass and twigs in India.
Transmigration is endless, like the great earth.
The tears you have shed in transmigration are greater than the waters in the oceans.
The mother’s milk you have drunk in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.
A great mountain would erode before the end of the eon.
A city filled with mustard seeds might be emptied before the end of an eon.
Even recollecting 100,000 eons per day you’ll never remember the beginning of transmigration.
There have been more eons than the sands in the Ganges river.
Like a stick falling on this side or that, beings are reborn in different realms.
The bones you’ve left behind in transmigration are greater than a mountain.
When you see someone suffer, know that you too have experienced that.
When you see someone happy, know that you too have experienced that.
The blood you have shed from being slaughtered or beheaded in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your mother.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your father.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your brother.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your sister.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your son.
It is not easy to find a being who has not been your daughter.
The Buddha recounts how peoples of the past had different names for the mountains of Rājagaha. Yet now they have all gone
Kassapa is content with robes, alms-food, lodging, and medicines.
Sāriputta approaches Kassapa and asks how it is that only someone who is keen and conscientious can realize freedom.
Kassapa approaches families like the moon, with humility, keeping his distance, and not getting involved. So when he teaches, it is with pure intentions.
Some mendicants approach families in the hope of receiving fine gifts or respect—but not Kassapa.
The Buddha points out that Kassapa has grown old, and urges him to give up his ascetic life and stay in a comfortable monastery.
The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, since certain students of Anuruddha and Ānanda have been competing to see who can teach better.
The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the mendicants have become stubborn and their good qualities are declining.

The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the senior mendicants used to set a good example, but now instead of respecting good practice, they respect fame and fortune.
The Buddha asserts that just as he has full mastery of all the meditation attainments and higher spiritual realizations, so does Kassapa.

When Kassapa is persuaded by Ānanda to go with him to teach the nuns, the nun Thullatissā compares him unfavorably to Ānanda, prompting Kassapa to issue a warning and make a bold claim of his spiritual mastery. This discourse appears to be set after the Buddha’s passing.

When several of Ānanda’s students disrobe, Kassapa admonishes him, calling him “boy”. The nun Thullanandā hears of this and criticizes Kassapa, claiming he formerly followed another teacher. But Kassapa refutes this, and gives an account of his going forth and first encounter with the Buddha.
Sāriputta asks Kassapa about whether a Realized One survives death.

sc_eng_sutta: The Counterfeit of the True Teaching
sc_blurb: Kassapa asks the Buddha why there are now more rules but fewer awakened mendicants. The Buddha replies that it is due to the arising of the counterfeit Dhamma, giving five factors that lead to decline
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, obstructing spiritual progress.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which catch you like fish on a hook.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which hit you like a harpoon hits a careless turtle.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which snare you like a long-haired goat in a briar patch.
A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is like a dung beetle proud of their ball of dung.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a lightning strike.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a poison dart.
A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a mangy jackal.
A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a bird in a gale.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, and attachment to them leads to a bad rebirth.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than a woman.

sc_eng_sutta: The Finest Lady in the Land
sc_blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than the finest lady in the land.
A laywoman should wish that if her son remains in the household life, he should be like Citta and Hatthaka. But if he becomes a monk, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to him!

A laywoman should wish that if her daughter remains in the household life, she should be like Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇḍakiyā. But if she becomes a nun, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to her!
Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone.
Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone, like a rope.
Material possessions, honor, and praise are even a problem for a perfected one, as they interfere with their meditation.
Devadatta provoked a schism due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
Devadatta’s wholesome root was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
Devadatta’s wholesome nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
Devadatta’s bright nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
Material possessions, honor, and praise led to Devadatta’s downfall, like the fruit of a plantain.
Prince Ajātasattu supplied devadatta with 500 carts of offerings, leading to his downfall.
Even someone who would not lie for the sake of their mother would so so when corrupted by material possessions.
Even someone who would not lie for the sake of their father and other relatives would so so when corrupted by material possessions.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the external sense objects in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense consciousness in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense contact in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on feelings in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on perceptions in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on intentions in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on cravings in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the four material elements in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the five aggregates in light of the three characteristics.
The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.

sc_eng_sutta: The Nine Discourses on Sights, Etc.
sc_blurb: The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the senses, aggregates, and elements in light of the three characteristics.
Rāhula asks how to see so that conceit no longer occurs. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self.
Rāhula asks how to see so conceit no longer occurs and one is peaceful. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self

While walking for alms down Vulture’s Peak, Venerable Moggallāna smiled at something invisible. Later, he told the Buddha it was a skeleton flying through the air, being pecked at by vultures. The Buddha confirmed that the man he had seen had been a butcher in his past life
As rafters depend on the roof-peak, unwholesome qualities depend on ignorance.
As the dirt in a fingernail is smaller than the great earth, the beings reborn as humans are few.
As a family with few men and many women is easily attacked, non-human beings may attack a mendicant without love.
Love is more beneficial than generosity.
As it is not possible to bend back a spear, it is not possible to overthrow a mendicant who has developed love.
Only a speedster could catch arrows in flight, yet conditioned phenomena perish faster than that.
As an ancient drum has disintegrated, so too will the true teachings disappear.
Warriors who sleep on wooden pillows remain vigilant, and so it is for the spiritual seeker.
A mendicant who overly associates with the laity is like an elephant calf who tries to copy the great bull elephants.
As a cat may suffer from eating too hastily, so a mendicant may suffer by not restraining senses.
A mangy jackal howls in discomfort, but even that would be a good rebirth for some.
An old jackal howls at dawn, but even they have more gratitude than some
Moggallāna reflects that second absorption is the true noble silence, and the Buddha encourages him to develop it.
Sāriputta says that not even if the Buddha changed would it cause him sorrow.
Sāriputta and Moggallāna come together for a discussion, which touches on the use of psychic powers and energy. The two great monks end up warmly praising each other.
When a certain monk neglects his duties in favor of solitude, other monks complain. The Buddha questions him, and finds that he is awakened.
The Buddha praises Venerable Sujāta as beautiful both inside and out.
Venerable Lakuṇṭaka Bhaddiya is a dwarf, considered to be ugly and unsightly. The Buddha warns the monks not to despise him as he had realized full awakening.
The Buddha praises Venerable Visākha Pañcāliputta for teaching the Dhamma.
Venerable Nanda wore pretty robes, a fancy bowl, and makeup, so the Buddha encouraged him to embrace simplicity.
Venerable Tissa admonished others but got upset when he was admonished. The Buddha encourages him to let go of his anger.
A monk named “Senior” likes to live alone, but the Buddha questions whether it is the true solitude.
The Buddha describes Venerable Mahākappina as thin, fair-skinned, with a big nose—and as awakened.
The Buddha praises two friends who are students of Venerable Mahākappina

The householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha for help in coping with old age. The Buddha says to reflect: “Even though I am afflicted in body, my mind will be unafflicted.” Later Sāriputta explains this in terms of the five aggregates.

A number of mendicants are heading for lands west, but the Buddha advises them to speak with Sāriputta before they go. Sāriputta reminds them that in foreign lands they will be scrutinized for their understanding, so they need to be able to answer questions on the teaching. He goes on to explain that the Dhamma is for the removal of desire for the five aggregates.

The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a verse from “The Questions of Māgandiya” of the Aṭṭhakavagga (Snp 4.9). Though the verse appears to be pitched at an ethical level, describing a sage intimate with none in the village, Mahākaccāna explains it in philosophical terms as non-attachment to the aggregates.

The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a passage on liberation from “The Questions of Sakka” (see MN 37 and DN 21). Mahākaccāna explains it in terms of freedom from attachment to the aggregates.
A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.
A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.
An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.
An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.
The aggregates are impermanent in the past and future as in the present.
The aggregates are suffering in the past and future as in the present.
The aggregates are not-self in the past and future as in the present.
Because the aggregates are impermanent, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
Because the aggregates are suffering, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
Because the aggregates are not-self, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
One should truly understand the five aggregates as impermanent, etc.
One should truly understand the five aggregates as suffering, etc.
One should truly understand the five aggregates as not-self.
Since the causes of the aggregates are impermanent, how can the aggregates be permanent?
Since the causes of the aggregates are suffering, how can the aggregates be free of suffering?
Since the causes of the aggregates are not-self, how can the aggregates be self?
Ānanda asks the Buddha what exactly is meant when we say that things cease. The Buddha explains it as the cessation of the aggregates.
The aggregates are the burden, a person carries that burden, craving takes up the burden, and letting go puts down the burden.
The aggregates are to be fully understood, and the full understanding is the ending of defilements.
Only by directly knowing the aggregates can one end suffering.
By letting go desire, the aggregates come to an end.
Before his awakening, the Buddha investigated the aggregates in terms of their gratification, drawback, and escape.
When the Buddha fully knew the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the five aggregates he became awakened.
Beings are attached to the five aggregates due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
If you enjoy the aggregates, you enjoy suffering.
The arising of the aggregates is the arising of suffering.
The aggregates are misery, desire for them is the root of misery.
The aggregates are fragile and their passing is not fragile.
Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?
Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates.
The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is reckoned by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.
The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is measured by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.

The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting. This was to become a critical aspect of later theories on the nature of change. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.

The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting, as applied to past, future, and present. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.
To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on disillusionment with the aggregates.
To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as impermanent.
To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as suffering.
To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as not-self.
Dwell with yourself as an island and refuge, with the Dhamma as an island and refuge. How? By investigating how suffering arises from identification with the aggregates.
Contemplation of the five aggregates as not-self is the path to the end of identity.
Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to freedom.
Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to letting go of views and ultimately to freedom.
When you identify anything as self, you always identify one or other of the five aggregates.
The distinction between “five aggregates” and “five grasping aggregates”.
The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa not to be conceited about the five aggregates.
The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa that any true ascetic understands the five aggregates.
Right view is seeing the aggregates as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.
Focusing properly on the five aggregates you see them as they are and become free.
Consciousness stands dependent on the other four aggregates, and this attachment is what fuels the cycle of rebirth.
Consciousness is like a seed that is planted in the soil of the other four aggregates and watered with craving.
The Buddha utters an enigmatic saying that non-identification leads to cutting off the fetters. A mendicant asks how to achieve this.

The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood each of the five aggregates in the light of each of the four noble truths. This discourse includes definitions of each of the aggregates.

To be fully accomplished, a mendicant should investigate the five aggregates in light of the four noble truths, as well as their gratification, drawback, and escape. In addition, they should investigate the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.

The Buddha declares that a mendicant is freed by wisdom by non-attachment to the aggregates, in just the same way as he himself. He then explains that the difference between himself and another awakened mendicant is simply that he was the first to discover the path and teach it to others.
In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.

Mahāli the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher Pūraṇa Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.
The five aggregates are burning.
All philosophers must accept that the five aggregates are described in language that refers to either the past, future, or present.
A mendicant comes to the Buddha to ask for instructions before going on retreat. The Buddha teaches them that in clinging to the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
In conceiving regarding the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
In seeking enjoyment in the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
One should let go of desire for what is impermanent, namely the five aggregates.
One should let go of desire for what is suffering, namely the five aggregates.
One should let go of desire for what is not-self, namely the five aggregates.
One should let go of desire for what does not belong to self, namely the five aggregates.
One should let go of desire for what appears tantalizing, namely the five aggregates.
Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
Venerable Surādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape.
Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence. A set of verses extols the perfected ones.
One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence.

When a lion emerges from its lair and roars, animals are terrified. Similarly, when the Buddha teaches of the impermanence of the aggregates, even the gods are filled with fear. This is illustrated with a set of verses.

One of the most extensive discourses in this collection begins with the Buddha saying that when anyone recollects a past life, all they are recollecting is the five aggregates. He then gives a distinctive set of definitions of the aggregates in terms of their functions, and discusses them from various aspects.

While staying at Kapilavatthu the Buddha dismissed the the Sangha for misbehaving. Later he decided to support them for the sake of the young mendicants. He reminds them that their livelihood is considered a lowly one, and that one should let go of bad thoughts and wrong views, and see the aggregates as impermanent.

Leaving behind the quarreling monks at Kosambi, the Buddha went to stay in the empty forest at Pārileyyaka. Ānanda brings some mendicants to receive a teaching, and one of them wonders how to see so as to end defilements in this very life. The Buddha teaches the 37 practices that lead to awakening, and then goes on to show that various ways of regarding the aggregates are conditioned phenomena.
On a sabbath day with the Sangha at Sāvatthi, the Buddha answers a series of ten questions on the aggregates.
Ānanda praises Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāniputta, and says that it was when hearing his teaching on the aggregates that he understood the Dhamma.

Venerable Tissa, the Blessed One’s paternal cousin, tells the monks that he is dissatisfied as a monk. When the Buddha hears of this, he calls Tissa to him, and questions him on the aggregates. As Tissa showed his understanding of each question, the Buddha praised him, lifting his spirits.

Venerable Yamaka had the wrong view that one whose defilements have ended is annihilated at death. The monks ask Sāriputta to help, and he asks Yamaka whether a realized one in this very life may be identified as one of the aggregates, or apart from them. Convinced, Yamaka lets go of his view and sees the Dhamma.

Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that a realized one is described in terms other than “still existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a realized one is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?

Venerable Vakkali is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, but says there is no point in seeing his physical body, as one who sees the Dhamma sees him. Later, Vakkali is taken to the Black Rock on Isigili, where he declares that he has no attachment to the aggregates, and takes his own life. The Buddha says that he had attained final extinguishment.

Venerable Assaji is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, and learns that Assaji has difficulty maintaining his meditation. The Buddha encourages him to contemplate the impermanence of the aggregates.

Venerable Khemaka is ill, and some senior mendicants ask Dāsaka to convey their concern to him. There follows a series of exchanges mediated by Dāsaka until eventually Khemaka, despite his illness, goes to see the other mendicants himself. The seniors are asking to determine Khemaka’s understanding of the Dhamma, and he says that although he has let go of the five lower fetters, he still has a residual attachment to the five aggregates.

Hearing that the Buddha, while on his deathbed, had announced a special punishment for him, Venerable Channa asks for teachings from the mendicants. Unsatisfied, he seeks out Ānanda, who teaches him the address to Kaccāyana (SN 12.15).
Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.
Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit and be free. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.
If you grasp at the aggregates as a self, you will meet with calamity, like a man swept down by a mountain river, grasping at grass or rushes.
The Buddha doesn’t dispute with the world; the world disputes with him. He has understood the five aggregates and explains them. Like a lotus, he was born in the swamp, but rises above it.

The Buddha gives a series of similes for the aggregates: physical form is like foam, feeling is like a bubble, perception is like a mirage, choices are like a coreless tree, and consciousness is like an illusion.
Nothing in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. In a past life, the Buddha was a great king with vast properties, but all those conditions have passed away.
A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. The Buddha answers using the simile of a little dirt under his fingernail.
A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence.
Transmigration has no knowable beginning; even the oceans, mountains, and this great earth will perish. But like a dog on a leash running around a post, beings remain attached to the aggregates.

A dog leashed to a post will always remain close to that post. In the same way, beings remain close to aggregates in this endless cycle of transmigration. The Buddha refers to a well-known painting called “Conduct”, and says the mind is even more diverse than that; and indeed, the animal realm is the most diverse of them all, and it is produced by the mind.

Contemplating the aggregates leads to liberation, but this may not be immediately apparent. The Buddha illustrates this with similes of a chook sitting on eggs, the wearing away of an axe handle, and the rotting of a ship’s rigging.
The perception of impermanence eliminates lust, ignorance, and conceit. Illustrated with a long series of similes.
The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths, phrased as “portions” or “sides”.
The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths in terms of suffering.
The aggregates considered in light of the four noble truths in terms of identity.
The aggregates are to be fully understood, ending the defilements is the full understanding of them, and an arahant is the one who has achieved this.
Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.
Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.
One who truly understand these five aggregates is a stream-enterer.
One who truly understand these five aggregates and is freed from them is a perfected one.
Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.
Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.
Ignorance is not understanding the aggregates.
Knowledge is understanding the aggregates.
A true Dhamma speaker teaches for letting go of the aggregates.
A true Dhamma speaker teaches for letting go of the aggregates.
An unawakened person is bound both internally and externally to the aggregates and grows old in bondage.
The Buddha questions the mendicants on the aggregates.
The Buddha questions the mendicants on the aggregates.
The aggregates are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.
The aggregates are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.

Mahākoṭṭhita asks what an ethical mendicant should focus on, and Sāriputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.

Mahākoṭṭhita asks what an educated mendicant should focus on, and Sāriputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.
Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
The Buddha explains to a mendicant that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape.
Sāriputta explains to Mahākoṭṭhita that knowledge is understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape.
Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.

Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of arising and ceasing, gratification, drawback, and escape, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.
Mahākoṭṭhita explains to Sāriputta that ignorance is not understanding the aggregates in terms of the four noble truths, while knowledge is understanding the aggregates.
The aggregates are like burning chaff.
Give up desire for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up lust for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up desire and lust for what is impermanent, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up desire for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up lust for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up desire and lust for what is suffering, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up desire for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up lust for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.
Give up desire and lust for what is not-self, i.e. the aggregates.
One gone forth should dwell full of disillusionment for the aggregates.
One gone forth should dwell contemplating impermanence in the aggregates.
One gone forth should dwell contemplating suffering in the aggregates.
One gone forth should dwell contemplating not-self in the aggregates.
Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the aggregates.
The ideas of “me’ and “mine” arise due to grasping the aggregates.
The idea that the self is identical with the cosmos arises due to grasping the aggregates.
Even subtle forms of self identification arise due to grasping the aggregates.
Wrong view arises due to grasping the aggregates.
Identity view arises due to grasping the aggregates.
View of self arises due to grasping the aggregates.
Fetters and shackles arise due to grasping the aggregates.
Fetters and holding arise due to grasping the aggregates.
When Ānanda wants to go on retreat, the Buddha advises him to contemplate the aggregates
Rādha asks the Buddha about Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates. Seeing in this way leads to freedom.
Rādha asks the Buddha about a the term “sentient being”, and the Buddha explains in terms of craving for the five aggregates. He compares such craving to a child playing with sandcastles.
Rādha asks the Buddha about the tie or conduit to rebirth, and the Buddha explains in terms of craving for the five aggregates.
The aggregates are to be fully understood, ending the defilements is the full understanding of them, and an arahant is the one who has achieved this.
Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.
Only a true ascetic fully understands the five aggregates.
One who truly understand these five aggregates is a stream-enterer.
One who truly understand these five aggregates and is freed from them is a perfected one.
Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.
Give up desire for the aggregates and they will come to an end.
Rādha asks the Buddha about Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about being subject to Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about impermanence, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of impermanent nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about suffering, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of painful nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about not-self, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is of selfless nature, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to end, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to vanish, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to arise, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha about what is liable to cease, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates.
Rādha asks the Buddha for a teaching before going on retreat, and the Buddha says that he should abandon desire, explaining what is liable to cease in terms of the five aggregates.
The Buddha tells Rādha that he should abandon desire, explaining what is liable to cease in terms of the five aggregates.

The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates. But by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent, such a view is given up and one becomes a stream-enterer.
The view of me and mine is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that the self is identical with the cosmos is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that “I might not be” is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view of annihilationism is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view of moral nihilism is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that denies causality is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that transmigration is fixed is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that the cosmos is eternal is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that the cosmos is not eternal is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that the cosmos is finite is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that the cosmos is infinite is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: The Soul and the Body Are Identical
sc_blurb: The view that the soul is the same thing as the body is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: The Soul and the Body Are Different Things
sc_blurb: The view that the soul and the body are different things is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
The view that a realized one still exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: A Realized One No Longer Exists
sc_blurb: The view that a realized one no longer exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: A Realized One Both Still Exists and No Longer Exists
sc_blurb: The view that a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: A Realized One Neither Still Exists Nor No Longer Exists
sc_blurb: The view that a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.
The various views arise from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, these views are given up.

sc_eng_sutta: Neither Still Exists Nor No Longer Exists
sc_blurb: The view that a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, this views is given up

sc_eng_sutta: The Self is Formed and Formless
The Self is Neither Formed Nor Formless
The Self Is Happy and Suffering
The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering
The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering
The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering

sc_blurb: One with faith in the teachings on the six interior sense fields is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six exterior sense fields is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of consciousness is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of contact is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of feeling is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of perception is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of intention is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of craving is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the four physical elements is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.

One with faith in the teachings on the five aggregates is called a “follower by faith”, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a “follower of the teachings”. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer
The arising of the six interior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six exterior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of consciousness is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of contact is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of feeling is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of perception is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of intention is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six kinds of craving is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the four physical elements is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the five aggregates is the arising of suffering
Desire for six interior sense fields is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six exterior sense fields is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of consciousness is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of contact is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of feeling is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of perception is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of intention is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for six kinds of craving is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for four physical elements is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge.
Desire for five aggregates is a corruption of the mind, and letting go such desire one is able to realize the various kinds of direct knowledge
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing first absorption without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing second absorption without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing third absorption without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing fourth absorption without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of infinite space without any thought of self.

Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of infinite consciousness without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of nothingness without any thought of self.

sc_eng_sutta: The Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception
sc_blurb: Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception without any thought of self.
Sāriputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards Ānanda asks why his face is so radiant. Sāriputta replies that he was practicing the attainment of cessation without any thought of self.

Sāriputta encountered a female wanderer named Sucimukhī, who asks him a series of enigmatic questions regarding what direction he faces when eating. Sāriputta denies all of them, explaining that they are various kinds of wrong livelihood.
Dragons may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously.
Dragons may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously. Those born spontaneously are the best.
Egg born dragons sometimes transform their bodies and observe the sabbath in order to get a good rebirth.
Womb born dragons sometimes transform their bodies and observe the sabbath in order to get a good rebirth.
Moisture born dragons sometimes transform their bodies and observe the sabbath in order to get a good rebirth.
Spontaneously born dragons sometimes transform their bodies and observe the sabbath in order to get a good rebirth.
One becomes an egg born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.
One becomes a womb born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.
One becomes a moisture dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.
One becomes a spontaneously born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become Egg-Born
sc_blurb: One becomes an egg born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts.

sc_eng_sutta: Thirty Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become Womb-Born, Etc.
sc_blurb: One becomes a womb born, moisture born, or spontaneously born dragon due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts
Phoenixes may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously.
Phoenixes may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously. Each of them may carry off a dragon of lower birth.
One becomes an egg born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.
One becomes a womb born, moisture born, or spontaneously born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become Egg-Born
sc_blurb: One becomes an egg born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts.

sc_eng_sutta: How Giving Helps to Become Womb-Born, Etc.
sc_blurb: One becomes a womb born, moisture born, or spontaneously born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life, the appropriate aspiration, and giving various gifts
Centaurs may live in fragrant roots and other vegetation.
Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a centaur.
Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in fragrant roots if they give fragrant roots.

sc_eng_sutta: Nine Discourses On Givers of Fragrant Heartwood, Etc.
sc_blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in various kinds of vegetation if they give the gift of that kind of vegetation.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps Rebirth in Fragrant Roots
sc_blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in fragrant roots if they give various gifts.

sc_eng_sutta: Ninety Discourses On How Giving Helps Rebirth in Fragrant Heartwood, etc.
sc_blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a god living in various kinds of vegetation if they give various gifts
Cloud gods may live in cool clouds, warm clouds, storm clouds, wind clouds, or rain clouds.
Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a cloud god.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become a Cool Cloud God
sc_blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a cloud god in a cool cloud if they give various gifts.

sc_eng_sutta: How Giving Helps to Become a Warm Cloud God, Etc.
sc_blurb: Someone of good conduct and appropriate aspiration may be reborn as a cloud god living in various kinds of cloud if they give various gifts.
When the cool cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes cool.
When the warm cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes warm.
When the storm cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes stormy.
When the wind cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes windy.
When the rain cloud gods decide to revel in their own element, the weather becomes rainy
The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing form.
The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing feeling.
The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing perception.
The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing choices.
The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not knowing consciousness.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Seeing Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not seeing the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Comprehending Form, Etc.
Five Discourses on Not Understanding Form, Etc.
Five Discourses on Not Penetrating Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not penetrating the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Distinguishing Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not discerning the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Detecting Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not discriminating the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Differentiating Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not differntiating the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Examining Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not examining the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Not Scrutinizing Form, Etc.
sc_blurb: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not closely examining the five aggregates.

sc_eng_sutta: Four Discourses on Not Directly Experiencing Form, Etc.
Projecting the Mind Purified by Immersion
Eight on Remaining and Emergence, Etc.
Seven on Emergence and Gladdening, Etc.
Six on Gladdening and Support, Etc.
Five on Support and Subjects, Etc.
Four on Subjects and Projection, Etc.

sc_blurb: The six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Interior as Impermanent in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Interior as Suffering in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Interior as Not-Self in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Exterior as Impermanent in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Exterior as Suffering in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.

sc_eng_sutta: The Exterior as Not-Self in the Three Times
sc_blurb: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.
The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.
The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.
The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.
Beings are attached to the six interior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
Beings are attached to the six exterior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
If you enjoy the six interior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.
If you enjoy the six exterior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.
The arising of the six interior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
The arising of the six exterior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
The “all” consists of the six interior and exterior sense fields.
The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up.

sc_eng_sutta: Giving Up By Direct Knowledge and Complete Understanding
sc_blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up by understanding.
Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and the associated consciousness and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is burning. This is the famous “third sermon” taught at Gayā’s Head to the followers of the three Kassapa brothers.
The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields, and the phenomena they condition, is weighed down.
The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.
The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.
The way to uproot all conceivings is to investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten on Liable to Be Reborn, Etc.

sc_blurb: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is afflicted.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up ignorance. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.

sc_eng_sutta: The Complete Understanding of All Grasping
sc_blurb: To fully understand grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.
To end grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.
To end grasping, investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.

Venerable Migajāla asks how one lives alone, and how with a partner. The Buddha says that so long as one is bound by desire to the senses, one lives with a partner. A mendicant free of such desire dwells alone, even if they live in close association with worldly people.

Venerable Migajāla asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are delightful, but if you hold to them you will suffer. Meditating on this while on retreat, Migajāla became awakened.
Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what Māra is. The Buddha says that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.

sc_eng_sutta: Samiddhi’s Question About a Sentient Being
sc_blurb: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what a “sentient being” is. The Buddha says that a sentient being is present so long as the senses exist.
Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what suffering is. The Buddha says that suffering is present so long as the senses exist.
Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what the world is. The Buddha says that the world is present so long as the senses exist.
A viper bit Venerable Upasena, but he remained poised, declaring that he had no identification with the six senses.

sc_eng_sutta: Upavāna on What is Apparent in the Present Life
sc_blurb: The teaching that can be realized in this very life is the desire for the senses, and letting go of that desire.

One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.

One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.

One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.
Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.
Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.
Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is impermanent.
Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is suffering.
Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is not-self.
Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent.
Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent. Then a mendicant truly understands, and sees everything differently.

Some mendicants check with the Buddha that it’s correct to say that the spiritual life is lived to end suffering. The Buddha answers that it is, and explains what that suffering is: the process of sense experience.
The “world” consisting of six sense experience is said to be falling apart.
The Buddhas of the past cannot be described in terms of the six senses.
The Buddha tells Ānanda that in the training of the noble one the “world” consisting of six sense experience is liable to wear out.
The Buddha tells Ānanda that the “world” consisting of six sense experience is empty because it is empty of self and what belongs to self.
Ānanda asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.

Sāriputta and Mahācunda visit Channa, who is ill. Channa says that he lacks for no care, but is in such great pain that he wishes to take his own life, insisting that he will do so blamelessly. Sāriputta tries to dissuade him, and questions him closely about attachment to the six senses. Later Channa does take his own life, and the Buddha confirmed that, despite Sāriputta’s doubts, he was indeed blameless.

Venerable Puṇṇa goes to the Buddha and asks for a teaching before he departs to the foreign land of Sunāparanta. The Buddha warns him that folk there are fierce, and questions whether he is ready for such a difficult assignment.
Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.
Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience.

Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience, or indeed, with the entire scope of the aggregates, elements, and senses.
The dyad is the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus.
Consciousness arises from the dyad of the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus. All these things are conditioned, impermanent, and constantly falling apart.
The six fields of contact lead to suffering if left unguarded, but if guarded lead to happiness. A lengthy set of verses illustrate this.

Venerable Māluṅkyaputta asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha wonders how to teach an old monk like him, then questions him on his desire for sense experience that has been or might be, and encourages him to simply let sense experience be. Māluṅkyaputta says he understands, and expands the Buddha’s teaching in a series of verses.

When a mendicant tolerates evil thoughts that arise from the senses, they are liable to decline. If they don’t tolerate them, they’re not liable to decline. When such thoughts not longer arise, they have mastered the senses.
When a mendicant lives without restraint regarding the senses, they are negligent. If they have restraint, they are diligent.
Non-restraint is delighting in the senses, restraint is not delighting in them.
Develop meditative immersion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.
Develop seclusion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.
Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?
Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience.

The Buddha’s former teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta claimed to be a knowledge master, a universal victor, who had excised the tumor. But a true knowledge master understands the senses, a victor is freed from them, and excising the tumor is being free from attachment to the body.
Someone who has given up attraction to the senses has arrived at the sanctuary.
Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the senses.
The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.
The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.
Conceit stems from clinging to the senses.
The interior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.
The interior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.
Without understanding the six interior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
Without understanding the six exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.

While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.
A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.
A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.

sc_eng_sutta: Traveling to the End of the World
sc_blurb: The Buddha states that the end of the world cannot be reached by traveling, yet it is impossible to end suffering without reaching the end of the world. The mendicants ask Ānanda to explain this enigmatic statement.

While practicing for awakening, the Buddha reflected that he should be diligent when his mind strayed to sense pleasures of the past, future, or present. He urges the mendicants to realize that place where the senses completely cease, and they ask Ānanda to explain this to them.
Sakka asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
The fairy Pañcasikha asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
A mendicant informs Sāriputta that one of his friends had disrobed. Sāriputta attributes this to lack of sense restraint, eating too much, and not being wakeful.

Realizing that his son Rāhula was ripe for awakening, the Buddha takes him for a personal teaching. He questions Rāhula on the impermanence of all the factors of sense experience, leading Rāhula to realize full freedom.
The exterior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.
The exterior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.
At the Great Wood, the householder Ugga of Vesālī asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

sc_eng_sutta: In the Land of the Vajjis
sc_blurb: At Hatthigāma, the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
At Nālandā, the householder Upāli asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

King Udena of Kosambi asks Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja how even young monks can maintain the celibate life. Piṇḍola says it’s because they see women as their sisters, mothers, or daughters. If this doesn’t work, they meditate on the ugliness of the body. Finally they exercise sense restraint.
At Rājagaha, the householder Soṇa asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
The householder Ghosita asks Ānanda about the diversity of elements, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.
