The householder Hāliddakāni asks Mahākaccāna about the relation between the diversity of elements and the diversity of contacts, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.
At Suṁsumāragira, the householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.

Students of the brahmin Lohicca make a racket while collecting firewood near Mahākaccāna’s hut. Mahākaccāna hushes them and recites a series of verses contrasting the virtuous brahmins of old with those of today. Taking umbrage, they tell Lohicca, who goes to Mahākaccāna to ascertain the truth. But when Lohicca hears what Mahākaccāna teach on the six senses, he is so impressed he goes for refuge.

A student of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan recommends to her the teaching of Venerable Udāyı̄, so she invites him for a meal. But when she displays a conceited attitude, he leaves without teaching. However, she corrects herself so he teaches her that pleasure and pain depend on the senses.
Not all mendicants have completed their work with regards to the six senses, but some of them have.
The Buddha speaks of the hell named the “six senses” where all one experiences is sheer pain and unpleasantness.
Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not. This teaching is illustrated with a long series of verses.
Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not.
Let go of what is not yours: the six interior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?
Let go of what is not yours: the six exterior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?
Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?
Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?
Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?
Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?
Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?
Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?
The six interior sense fields are not yours, but are old kamma, generated by choices in past lives. This is explained in terms of the four noble truths.

sc_eng_sutta: The Impermanent as Conducive to Extinguishment
sc_blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent.

sc_eng_sutta: The Suffering as Conducive to Extinguishment
sc_blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.
The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.
The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent, suffering, and not-self.
One with no “student” and no “teacher” dwells in happiness. Here the Buddha plays with the Pali words such that “student” means “one who dwells within” and “teacher” means “one who assails”.

sc_eng_sutta: What’s the Purpose of the Spiritual Life?
sc_blurb: If anyone asks why we live the holy life, it is for the ending of suffering.
How is it that a mendicant can declare their awakening? By understanding whether any desire arises from sense stimuli.
One is accomplished in the sense faculties by being freed from attachment to them.
A speaker on the Dhamma is someone who teaches for letting go of the senses.

sc_eng_sutta: The Interior and the End of Relishing
sc_blurb: Right view is seeing the interior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.

sc_eng_sutta: The Exterior and the End of Relishing
sc_blurb: Right view is seeing the exterior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.

sc_eng_sutta: Focus, the Interior, and the End of Relishing
sc_blurb: Focusing properly on the interior sense fields you see them as they are and become free.

sc_eng_sutta: Focus, the Exterior, and the End of Relishing
sc_blurb: Focusing properly on the exterior sense fields you see them as they are and become free.

sc_eng_sutta: On Immersion at Jīvaka’s Mango Grove
sc_blurb: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.

sc_eng_sutta: On Retreat at Jīvaka’s Mango Grove
sc_blurb: A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.
Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is impermanent, i.e. the process of sense experience.
Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is suffering, i.e. the process of sense experience.
Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is not-self, i.e. the process of sense experience.
Wrong view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.
Identity view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.
View of self arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.

sc_eng_sutta: Desire and Greed for the Impermanent Interior
Desire, Etc. for the Suffering Interior
Desire, Etc. for the Not-Self Interior
Desire, Etc. for the Impermanent Exterior
Desire, Etc. for the Suffering Exterior
Desire, Etc. for the Not-Self Exterior
The Interior Was Impermanent in the Past
The Interior Will Be Impermanent in the Future
The Interior Is Impermanent in the Present
The Interior as Suffering in the Three Times
The Interior as Not-Self in the Three Times
The Exterior as Impermanent in the Three Times
The Exterior as Suffering in the Three Times
The Exterior as Not-Self in the Three Times
The Interior and What’s Impermanent in the Past
The Interior and What’s Impermanent in the Future
The Interior and What’s Impermanent in the Present
The Interior and What’s Suffering in the Three Times
The Interior and What’s Not-Self in the Three Times
The Exterior and What’s Impermanent in the Three Times
The Exterior and What’s Suffering in the Three Times
The Exterior and What’s Not-Self in the Three Times

sc_blurb: In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the sense organs, the current is the sense objects.
In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the delights of sense stimuli.
Sense pleasures are like a baited hook.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Latex-Producing Tree
sc_blurb: Like a tree that yields sap when cut, so long as desire is present it will be activated by the senses.

Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.

Kāmabhū asks Ānanda whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.
Udāyı̄ notes to Ānanda that the Buddha has taught the body as not-self; what then of consciousness? Ānanda then explains how consciousness arises dependent on conditions.
It would be better for the sense organs to be pierced with red-hot spikes than to get attached to a pleasant sense experience.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of Hands and Feet (1st)
sc_blurb: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of Hands and Feet (2nd)
sc_blurb: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.
The Buddha strings a series of powerful similes—vipers, murderers, an empty village, and more—into an extended parable of the dangers of existence and the way of escape.
When a mendicant has three qualities they live happily: sense restraint, moderation in eating, and wakefulness.
A parable of a jackal who fails to eat a tortoise who stays still, with limbs retracted, like a mendicant guarding the senses.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Tree Trunk (1st)
sc_blurb: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. A mendicant asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item. A cowherd named Nanda was listening, and determined to go forth.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Tree Trunk (2nd)
sc_blurb: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. Venerable Kimbila asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item.

The Buddha is invited to teach in a new hall in Kapilavatthu. Late at night, after teaching the Sakyans, the Buddha invites Moggallāna to teach. He speaks on the mental corruption that flows from attachment to the senses.

The Buddha defines the things that entail suffering as the five aggregates, and urges mendicants to be free of desire for the six senses, giving a series of vivid similes. He then speaks of how even for a mendicant practicing restraint a lapse of mindfulness might occur from time to time.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Parrot Tree
sc_blurb: A mendicant goes to a series of teachers and asks how vision is purified. Dissatisfied with all their answers, he complains to the Buddha, who illustrates his quandary with the famous simile of the Kiṁsuka tree. Just as the same Kiṁsuka tree might be described differently by people focusing on the leaves, or the fruit, or the bark, etc., so too the various teachers each speak of the aspect of Dhamma most meaningful to them.

One should restrain the senses like a farmer watching over a field. The Buddha gives the parable of a man bewitched when he first hears a lute. He takes apart the instrument in search of the sound, but is disillusioned when no sound is found.
The senses are like a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, a jackal, and a monkey all tied up together, pulling this way and that. Mindfulness is like a post that keeps them grounded.

The six senses are like a sheaf of barley struck with six flails; and the desire for rebirth is a seventh flail. The Buddha goes on to speak of the cunning trap of the gods; but the trap of Māra, conceit, is even more subtle.
There are three feelings, and a meditator practicing immersion can understand them.
There are three feelings, and all of them are suffering.
One should give up desire for pleasant feeling, aversion for painful feeling, and ignorance regarding neutral feeling.
Ordinary people think the ocean is a bottomless abyss; but really, it is the three feelings.
See pleasant feeling as painful, painful feeling as a dart, and neutral feeling as impermanent.

Both ordinary and awakened people experience the three feelings. The difference is that when an ordinary person is stricken with feeling, they react, creating more suffering, whereas an awakened person responds with equanimity.
A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.
A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.
The three feelings are impermanent.
The three feelings are each produced by the appropriate contact.
A mendicant wonders how there can be three kinds of feeling, yet all of them are suffering.
Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky. With illustrative verses.
Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky.
Feelings arise in the body like guests in a hotel.
The Buddha explains the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
The Buddha asks about the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
The Buddha explains the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
The Buddha asks about the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
The chamberlain Pañcakaṅga disagreed with Venerable Udāyī about how many kinds of feeling the Buddha taught. The Buddha affirms that each is a genuine teaching, valid in different contexts.
The Buddha has taught many different kinds of feeling, valid in different contexts.
When the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka asks if all feelings are caused by karma in past lives. The Buddha denies this, asserting that feelings have many different causes.

sc_eng_sutta: The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight
sc_blurb: The Buddha explains the different kinds of feelings analyzed into 108 aspects.
A mendicant asks the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.
Before his awakening the Buddha reflected on feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
At his awakening, the Buddha saw feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
Several mendicants ask the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.
One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
There are three feelings: painful, pleasant, neutral.
The Buddha explains feelings as spiritual and carnal, associated with worldly states and with deep meditation.
Five things that make a woman either agreeable or disagreeable to men.
Five things that make a man either agreeable or disagreeable to women.
Five kinds of suffering that only women are subject to, not men.
A woman who is selfish, envious, and lustful has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five bad qualities has a bad rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman with five good qualities has a good rebirth.
A woman who keeps the five precepts has a good rebirth.
A woman with five powers lives confident at home.
A woman with five powers lives at home having won over her husband.
A woman with five powers lives at home with her husband under her control.
A man with one power has a woman under his control: authority.
A woman may be complete with five powers.
A woman lacking in any of the five powers may be expelled from a family.
It is not because of beauty, wealth, relatives, or sons that a woman has a good rebirth, but because of ethical conduct.
For a woman who has not made merit, five things are hard to come by.
A woman with five qualities lives confidently at home.
A woman who grows in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom acquires the best.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about extinguishment and the path to realize it.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about perfection (arahantship) and the path to realize it.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta who in the world are proponents of Dhamma.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about the purpose of the spiritual path.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about who has attained consolation.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about who has attained supreme consolation.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is feeling.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is a defilement.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is ignorance.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is craving.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what are the floods.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is grasping.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About States of Existence
sc_blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about the three realms of rebirth.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta about suffering.
The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is identity.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About What’s Hard to Do
sc_blurb: The wanderer Jambukhādaka asks Sāriputta what is difficult to do in this teaching and training.
The wanderer Sāmaṇḍaka asks Sāriputta what is difficult to do in this teaching and training.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the First Absorption
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the first absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Second Absorption
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the second absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Third Absorption
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the third absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Fourth Absorption
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the fourth absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Dimension of Infinite Space
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of infinite space was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Dimension of Infinite Consciousness
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of infinite consciousness was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Dimension of Nothingness
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of nothingness was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: A Question About the Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception
sc_blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the signless immersion was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

Moggallāna ascended to the heaven of the Thirty-Three to address Sakka, the lord of gods, and his extensive retinue. He spoke in praise of going for refuge, as it leads to heaven. Sakka affirmed this on multiple occasions, adding that gods who had gone for refuge and kept ethics surpassed the other deities in the heavens.
The dialogue in SN 40.10 is repeated with a series of other deities.

Citta the householder hears of a conversation among the monks regarding the distinction between the fetters and the things that are fettered. He goes to ask them on this topic, but they are unable to give a satisfactory answer, so he explained it to them. It is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen.
Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them about the diversity of the elements, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer.

Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them what is the cause of the ten metaphysical questions and the 62 views of the Brahmajāla Sutta, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer. Citta realizes that Isidatta is in fact an unseen friend of his from Avantī. He offers to support him with requisites, but Isidatta left, never to return.

Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. When they left he followed them, and witnessed the junior monk Venerable Mahaka performing a psychic feat. Citta approached Mahaka in his hut and asked him to demonstrate his skills, and Mahaka obliged. Citta offers to support him with requisites, but Mahaka left, never to return.
Venerable Kāmabhū asks Citta to explain an enigmatic verse on a “one-spoked chariot”. After a brief consideration, Citta is able to explain it in detail.
Citta asks Kāmabhū about the different kinds of processes (saṅkhāra) in a series of questions that lead to the most profound of meditation experiences.

Venerable Godatta asks Citta whether the liberations of measurelessness, nothingness, emptiness, and signlessness are different states, or just different words for the same thing. Citta explains that they are both: they are terms for different meditation experiences, but may also be used of perfection or arahantship.

sc_eng_sutta: The Jain Ascetic of the Ñātika Clan
sc_blurb: The Jain leader Mahāvīra, known as Nigaṇṭha Nātaputa in the Buddhist tradition, is visited by Citta. Mahāvīra asks him whether he believes in a certain state of immersion. When Citta replies that he doesn’t go by faith in the Buddha on this point, Mahāvīra is delighted. But it turns out Citta doesn’t need faith, as he experiences such a state for himself.

Citta meets with the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of his, and asks what gains he has realized from the spiritual life. Kassapa admits he has realized no higher attainments, whereupon Citta reveals he has realized many such attainments. Kassapa decides to ordain as a Buddhist mendicant.
When Citta was on his deathbed, rather than receiving comfort, he gave comfort and teaching to those present.
A headman known for his aggressive nature approaches the Buddha and asks how to give up irritability. The Buddha points out that such reactions are fueled by greed, hate, and delusion.

Talapuṭa the head of a troupe of performers asks the Buddha whether the belief that performers have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by inciting lust they head to a bad rebirth. Talapuṭa is distressed and asks to ordain.

Yodhājı̄va the professional warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and takes refuge.

Hatthāroha the elephant warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Hatthāroha is distressed and takes refuge.

Assāroha the cavalry warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and asks to ordain.

The chief Asibandhakaputta asks whether the rituals advocated by the western brahmins can bring a person to heaven. The Buddha asserts that only good deeds can take you to a good rebirth, and rituals have no effect.

The chief Asibandhakaputta asks the Buddha why, if he has equal compassion for all, he teaches some more than others. The Buddha answers with a simile of a field: a farmer knows to put most of their effort into the fertile land.

The Buddha asks the chief Asibandhakaputta, a Jain, how Mahāvīra the Jain leader teaches his followers. He replies that you go to a rebirth depending on what you usually do. But the Buddha points out that even a killer only spends a small amount of time actually killing. The Buddha’s approach is to point out that deeds have results, and to encourage the abandoing of bad deeds and the adoption of good deeds.

Mahāvīra asks Asibandhakaputta to refute the Buddha on behalf of the Jains. He suggests to try to trap the Buddha with a dilemma: he claims to have compassion for householders, yet visits them with a large Saṅgha in a time of scarcity. But the Buddha says no family has been harmed from this.

Several members of the king’s retinue criticize the Buddhist mendicants for accepting offerings of money. Chief Maṇicūḷaka is among them, and he visits the Buddha to find out the truth. The Buddha categorically denies the accusation.
The chief Bhadraka asks the Buddha about the origin and ending of suffering, and the Buddha points out that a loss among Bhadraka’s own community would cause him suffering, due to his attachment.

The chief Rāsiya asks whether the Buddha completely rejects all forms of asceticism. The Buddha denies that this is the case, and explains what he means by the middle way in a lengthy disquisition, covering useful and useless forms of asceticism.
The chief Pāṭaliya asks whether the Buddha knows magic. He says he does—but that does not make him a magician.

sc_eng_sutta: Placing the Mind and Keeping it Connected

sc_blurb: While staying in Toraṇavatthu, King Pasenadi wishes to visit a spiritual teacher, and the nun Khemā is highly recommended to him. He asks her about whether a realized one still exists after death, and she says this is not answerable. Later he visits the Buddha, who replies in exactly the same way.

Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that a realized one is described in terms other than “still existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a realized one is not even apprehended in this life, so how can they be described after death?
Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that to answer this would be to get involved in the five aggregates, something that a Realized One is free from.
Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that one who understands the five aggregates would not think in such terms.
Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that only someone who has desire for the five aggregates would think in such terms.

Sāriputta asks Mahākoṭṭhita whether a Realized One exists after death. Mahākoṭṭhita says that only someone who delights in the five aggregates would think in such terms, and offers a variety of further explanations of the same point.

The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Moggallāna the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. Moggallāna says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the six senses. Vacchagotta then asks the Buddha the same questions.

The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. He says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the five aggregates.

The wanderer Vacchagotta reports to the Buddha a conversation among ascetics on the views of the six heretical teachers as to where a perfected one is reborn. Unsure of what the Buddha’s position was, he asks how it is to be understood. The Buddha says it is like a flame that burns dependent on fuel, and goes out when that fuel is extinguished.
Vacchagotta asks the Buddha whether a self exists, but the Buddha is silent. When Ānanda later asks him why he didn’t answer, the Buddha replied that it was to avoid misunderstanding.

The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna whether a Realized One exists after death. He answers that the basis for describing a Realized One no longer applies. Vacchagotta is impressed that such a junior monk understands this subtle matter.
Following ignorance comes the wrong eightfold path. But the right eightfold path follows true knowledge.

When Ānanda says that good friendship is half the spiritual path, the Buddha rebukes him, saying that it is in fact the whole of the spiritual path. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.
When Sāriputta says that good friendship is the whole of the spiritual path, the Buddha praises him. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.

Ānanda sees the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi resplendent on his all-white chariot. He asks the Buddha whether there is a similarly divine vehicle in Buddhism. The Buddha responds by drawing a detailed set of analogies between the eightfold path and a chariot.
When asked what is the purpose of the spiritual path, you should answer that it is the ending of suffering.
A mendicant asks what is the purpose of the spiritual path, and the Buddha answers that it is the ending of suffering.
A mendicant asks about Nibbāna and the deathless.
The Buddha presents the eightfold path together with a detailed analysis of each factor. It should be assumed that these explanations apply wherever the eightfold path is taught.
A mendicant with wrong view will develop the path in the wrong way, harming themselves as if grabbing a sharp spike the wrong way.
The wanderer Nandiya asks how many things lead to extinguishment.
The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.
The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.
A mendicant asks how a person is a “trainee”.
The eightfold path does not arise apart from a Realized One.
The eightfold path does not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.
The eight pure factors of the path do not arise apart from a Realized One.
The eight pure factors of the path do not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.
In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the unholy life, or the unspiritual path. It is the wrong eightfold path.
In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the holy life, or the spiritual path. It is the right eightfold path.
In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the spiritual path, one who follows the spiritual path, and the goal of the spiritual path.
The wrong eightfold path is a wrong state; the right eightfold path is a right state.
The factors of the wrong eightfold path are unskillful qualities; those of the right eightfold path are skillful qualities.
The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.
Regardless of whether one is a lay person or a renunciate, the Buddha praises the right way, not the wrong way. The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.
A bad person practices wrong eightfold path; a good person practices the right eightfold path.
A bad person practices wrong eightfold path, and a worse person has wrong knowledge and wrong liberation, too; a good person is the opposite.
Someone without the eightfold path is easily knocked over, like a pot without a stand.
The eightfold path is the necessary prerequisite for right immersion (samādhi).
The eightfold path is developed to understand the three feelings.
The Buddha taught the eightfold path in order to give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
The wrong eightfold path is wrong practice; the right eightfold path is right practice.
Practicing the wrong eightfold path is wrong; practicing the right awakening path is right.
Neglecting the eightfold path you neglect the path to the end of suffering.
The eightfold path leads from the near to the far shore. With a long set of verses.
The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for the fading away of lust.

sc_eng_sutta: Six Discourses on Giving Up Fetters, Etc.
sc_blurb: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for giving up fetters, etc.
If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for final extinguishment without anything left over.
As the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the eightfold path.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc. (1st)
sc_blurb: As the dawn precedes the sun, ethics, enthusiasm, confidence, right view, and diligence precede the eightfold path.

sc_eng_sutta: Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (1st)
sc_blurb: As the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the eightfold path.

sc_eng_sutta: Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc. (2nd)
Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (2nd)
Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc. (1st)
Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (1st)
Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc. (2nd)
Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (2nd)
Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc.
Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind
Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc.
Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (2nd)
Five Discourses on Slanting to the Ocean
Five Discourses on Sloping to the East

sc_blurb: Develop the eightfold path to abandon the three cravings. This sutta is doubled by replacing taṇhā with another form of the same word, tasina. This variation is found in Burmese but not Sinhalese manuscripts.

Develop the eightfold path to abandon the three cravings. This sutta is doubled by replacing taṇhā with another form of the same word, tasina. This variation is found in Burmese but not Sinhalese manuscripts.
Dragons nurture their strength in the Himalayas, then enter the rivers and reach the ocean. So too, a mendicant nurtures ethics and then develops the seven awakening factors.
Just as the body depends on food, the awakening factors depend on nutriment. The Buddha gives specific conditions for each of the factors.
Here the awakening factors are described in the context of hearing the teachings and reflecting on them. This leads to full enlightenment, or at least to some lesser attainment.
The various awakening factors can be donned at different times of the day, like a man who puts on bright colored clothes whenever he wants.
They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.

The wanderer Kuṇḍaliya points out that some ascetics argue for the sake of winning debates. But the Buddha says his path is for the sake of liberation. Kuṇḍaliya asks what leads to liberation, and the Buddha traces a sequence of conditions back to sense restraint.
The awakening factors lead to extinguishment, like rafters holding up the roof peak.
Sāriputta asks Upavāṇa how one can reflect and see the awakening factors in oneself.
The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Realized One.
The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Holy One’s training.
Just as living creatures are based on the earth, the awakening factors are based on ethics.
Just as the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the awakening factors.
Just as the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the awakening factors.
When Mahākassapa was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
When Mahāmoggallāna was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
When the Buddha was sick, Mahācunda taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
The awakening factors lead from the near to the far shore.
Those who neglect the awakening factors neglect the path to the end of suffering.
The awakening factors are noble and emancipating.
The awakening factors lead to disenchantment.
They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.

sc_eng_sutta: A Teaching on the Awakening Factors
sc_blurb: A simple statement on the awakening factors.
Frequently focusing on things tends to promote similar qualities, whether good (awakening factors) or bad (hindrances).
Improper attention grows the hindrances, proper attention grows the awakening factors.
The awakening factors lead to non-decline.
The awakening factors lead to the ending of craving.
The awakening factors lead to the cessation of craving.
The awakening factors partake of penetration.
Nothing is as effective for getting rid of fetters as the awakening factors.
Venerable Udāyı̄ celebrates his progress on the path, gaining faith as a householder, going forth, and realizing the Dhamma. Now he develops the awakening factors for the end of suffering.
Skillful qualities are rooted in diligence, which promotes the awakening factors.
Skillful qualities are rooted in proper attention, which promotes the awakening factors.
Hindrances sully the mind like impurities in gold.
Awakening factors purify the mind and lead to liberation.
Improper attention promotes the hindrances; proper attention promotes the awakening factors.
The awakening factors lead to growth and non-decline.
Hindrances sully the mind, awakening factors purify it.
Listening to the teaching, the hindrances are given up and the awakening factors developed.
As some large trees with small seeds will overgrow and ruin other trees, so the hindrances overgrow and ruin the mind.
The hindrances cause blindness, the awakening factors cause vision.
Anyone who abandons the three kinds of discrimination does so due to the awakening factors.
As the Wheel-turning Monarch manifests seven treasures, the Realized One manifests the seven awakening factors.
The awakening factors crush Māra’s army.
A stupid person has not developed the awakening factors.
A wise person has developed the awakening factors.
A person who has not developed the awakening factors is called “poor”.
A person who has developed the awakening factors is called “prosperous”.
As the dawn precedes the sunrise, so too good friendship precedes the awakening factors.
No internal factor helps the awakening factors so much as proper attention.
No external factor helps the awakening factors so much as good friendship.
The Buddha spells out in detail the factors that nourish the hindrances, and those that nourish the awakening factors.

Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains by giving a detailed analytical treatment that he says is beyond the scope of the wanderers.
Which awakening factors should be developed when the mind is tired, and which when it is energetic? And what is always useful?

Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the four Brahmā meditations, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains the detailed connection between the Brahmā meditations and the awakening factors, which taken together lead to liberation.

The brahmin Saṅgārava asks why sometimes verses stay in memory while other times they don’t. The Buddha replies that it is due to the presence of either the hindrances of awakening factors. He gives a set of similes illustrating each of the hindrances with different bowls of water.

Prince Abhaya reports Pūraṇa Kassapa’s view that there is no cause for ignorance or knowledge, and asks the Buddha’s opinion. The Buddha replies that the cause of ignorance is the hindrances, and the cause of knowledge is the awakening factors.
A series of passages on the benefits of meditating on a skeleton. Some editions treat the sections as separate suttas.

sc_eng_sutta: More on the Ganges River, Etc.
Another Series on a Realized One, Etc.

sc_blurb: At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the “way to convergence”, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the practice of situational awareness.

When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha issues an unexpected rebuke. Evidently the mendicant had been badly behaved; but now, he insists, he is sincere. The Buddha relents, and teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
Newly ordained mendicants should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; trainees are practicing them, and perfected ones have perfected the practice.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a complete heap of what is skillful.

The parable of the quail and the hawk. When the quail ventured outside her ancestral territory, she became vulnerable. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
The parable of the foolish monkey who gets trapped in tar when it ventures outside its ancestral territory. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

The parable of the cook. They present different kinds of dishes to the king, and observe which the king likes. In the same way, a mendicant observes why their meditation succeeds or fails. When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation succeeds it leads to giving up hindrances and entering immersion.

The Buddha decides to spend his final rains retreat at Vesālī in Beluvagāmaka. During the retreat he becomes very ill, but later recovers. Ānanda wonders who will guide the Saṅgha when the Buddha dies, but the Buddha says they should be their own refuge, grounded on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

When Ānanda visits the nuns’s quarters they tell him that their meditation is prospering to higher and higher levels. Ānanda reporrts the good news to the Buddha, who speaks of two ways of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation: directed and undirected.
Sāriputta asks the Buddha what is a great man, and the Buddha says it is someone whose mind has been freed by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

Sāriputta boldly claims that no-one has ever, or will ever, be more enlightened than the Buddha. He admits that he cannot read the minds of all the Buddhas, but he understands a principle of the Dhamma: all those who become awakened do so by giving up the five hindrances, practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, and developing the seven awakening factors.

Sāriputta dies of illness, and the novice Cunda together with Ānanda take his bowl and robes and report the sad news to the Buddha. The Buddha dispels Ānanda’s sadness by speaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
After the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna (whose actual death is unrecorded in the canon), the Buddha says the Saṅgha looks empty; yet he is not sad.
When Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
When Venerable Uttiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the end of suffering.
Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence.

Two acrobats discuss whether one should support the other, or the other way around. The Buddha says they should support each other. In the same way we should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation both for one’s own benefit and to protect others.

sc_eng_sutta: The Finest Lady in the Land
sc_blurb: A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That’s mindfulness!
Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the ethical virtues encouraged by the Buddha—what is their purpose? To develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching declines. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
A simple teaching on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

A brahmin asks the Buddha about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. The Buddha says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone a trainee. It is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone an adept. It is someone who has fully developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Anuruddha claims to have developed the various direct knowledges by practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
When the householder Sirivaḍḍha is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.
When the householder Mānadinna is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.
The full knowledge of mindfulness meditation was not learned before the Buddha.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to peace.
Someone who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the noble path.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead from the near to the far shore.
Mindfulness is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. Situational awareness is watching the arising and passing of feelings, thoughts, and perceptions.
When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed, perfection or non-return may be expected.
Developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, desire is abandoned.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to realizing the deathless.
The development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
The Buddha teaches the simple passage on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and an advanced analysis, which involves contemplating them as impermanent.
Develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, don’t let the deathless be lost.
The causes for the origination and cessation of the phenomena upon which the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are grounded.
The Buddha tells the mendicants how, just after his awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supported the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence
Be mindful by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a heap of the skillful.
When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on restraint in the code of monastic rules.
When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on good bodily, verbal, and mental conduct.
You should encourage your friends to practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to understand the three feelings.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to give up the defilements.

sc_eng_sutta: Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, Etc.

sc_blurb: The five faculties are faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.
One who understands the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.
One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.
One who is freed after understanding the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.
A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.
A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
Each of the five faculties should be seen in a particular set of teachings.
The Buddha gives a short explanation of each of the five faculties.
The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of each of the five faculties.
The Buddha explains the five faculties in terms of how they are obtained.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.
One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. One who has none of them at all is an outsider.
Someone who develops the faculties is said to be equipped with faculties.
The five faculties lead to the ending of defilements in this very life.
The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the five faculties.
Three faculties: femininity, masculinity, and vitality.
Three faculties relating to stages in the realization of awakening.
Depending on the strength of the five faculties, one is perfected, or reaches a lesser attainment.
Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who understand these is a stream-enterer.
Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who is freed by understanding these is perfected.
The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the six faculties.
A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.
A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
Five faculties: pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.
One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a stream-enterer.
One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a perfected one.
A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.
A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.
The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail.
The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.
The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Fire Sticks
sc_blurb: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity arise dependent on the appropriate contact, like sticks making fire.

The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are taught in a detailed exposition that treats them in an unusual order. The abandoning of each is related to the attainment of a particular meditative absorption.
When Ānanda sees the Buddha’s sense faculties fading, the Buddha speaks on the decrepitude of old age, including verses.
The brahmin Uṇṇābha points out that the five physical sense faculties do not share a common domain, so where do they come together? In the mind. Uṇṇābha pursues the teaching all the way to Nibbāna.

The Buddha discusses the five faculties and the five powers. They are like a river that flows around a central island. From one point of view they can be considered different, but from another they are just the same stream.
Sāriputta does not rely on faith in saying that the five faculties lead to the deathless, for he has seen this for himself.
Having developed wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening, as wisdom fulfills the other faculties.
Having developed wisdom and immersion a mendicant may declare their awakening.
Having developed energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.
Having developed faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.
Having developed mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom the mendicant Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja declared his awakening.
The Buddha asks Sāriputta whether a noble disciple doubts the Buddha. Not only does he have faith, replies Sāriputta, but the other faculties each come to be developed in turn.
Just as the lion is the king of beasts, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.

sc_eng_sutta: In the Land of the Mallas
sc_blurb: Only when noble wisdom arises do the other four faculties become stable.
How does someone recognize that they are a trainee? By understanding the four noble truths and the five faculties. But only a perfected one fully embodies these qualities.
Just as all footprints fit into that of an elephant, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.
Just as red sandalwood is the best of fragrances, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.
When established in diligence, the five faculties come to be developed.
Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the five faculties lead to the deathless.
A mendicant honors the Realized One and his teaching for the sake of the supreme sanctuary.
The five faculties only arise in the dispensation of a Realized One.
The five faculties only arise in the training of a Holy One.
The four bases of psychic power lead from the near to the far shore.
One who has neglected the four bases of psychic power has neglected the path to the end of suffering.
The four bases of psychic power are noble and emancipating.
The four bases of psychic power lead to dispassion.
Those who have developed psychic powers in part have developed the four bases of psychic power in part.
Those who have developed psychic powers in full have developed the four bases of psychic power in full.
Whatever mendicants realize perfection do so by developing the four bases of psychic power.
It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that the Realized One is called a Buddha.
On the night of his awakening, understanding and vision came to the Buddha regarding the four bases of psychic power.
The Buddha says he could live to the end of the eon due to developing the four bases of psychic power. But Ānanda doesn’t get the hint.
The Buddha recounts the process of inquiry that lead to him fully understanding the four bases of psychic power, as well as the powers that result from that.
The four bases of psychic power are very beneficial.
An analysis of the four bases of psychic power showing how enthusiasm, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry work in the context of advanced meditation.

When lazy monks were wasting time, the Buddha asks Moggallāna to stir them up. He shakes with his toe the large building in which they were staying, terrifying the monks. They sought refuge in the Buddha, and he taught them the four bases of psychic power.

Ānanda explains to the brahmin Uṇṇābha that the spiritual path is lived to give up desire through the the four bases of psychic power. But Uṇṇābha says this is a contradiction, as desire is itself one of the four bases. Ānanda resolves the contradiction with the simile of a man walking to a park.
Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.
Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.
It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.

sc_eng_sutta: A Teaching on Psychic Power, Etc.
sc_blurb: The Buddha distinguishes between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
The Buddha teaches the bases for psychic power and analyzes them in detail.
Before his awakening, the Buddha reflected on the path for developing the bases of psychic power.
Ānanda asks the Buddha whether he travels to the Brahmā realm in a mind-made body or in a physical body.
It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.
The four bases for psychic power are desire, energy, higher mind, and inquiry.
The four bases for psychic power lead to perfection or once-return.
The four bases for psychic power lead to seven benefits; perfection or one of the lesser attainments.
The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
Moggallāna is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.
The Realized One is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.

While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally, in terms of origin and cessation, and developing power over perceptions.

While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally.

sc_eng_sutta: On the Bank of the Sutanu
sc_blurb: When some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what a trainee mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what an adept mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
When Sāriputta ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the ending of craving.
Even if kings beg them to disrobe, a mendicant who has developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation is unmoved. Their mind flows to Nibbāna like the Ganges to the sea.
Sāriputta asks why Anuruddha looks so peaceful, and he replies it is due to developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he remains equanimous even though ill. He replies that it is due to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
By developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation Anuruddha surveys a thousand world systems.

sc_eng_sutta: Where All Paths of Practice Lead

sc_blurb: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.
Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed together with the seven factors of awakening.
Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.
Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or non-return.
Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or one of the lesser attainments.
When the Buddha asks Venerable Ariṭṭha about breath meditation, his answer, while not incorrect, does not do full justice to the practice.
The Buddha sees Venerable Mahākappina meditating nearby and points out that his steadiness and tranquility are due to practicing breath meditation.

Before his awakening the Buddha generally practiced breath meditation, which kept him alert and peaceful and led to the ending of defilements. One who wishes for any of the higher fruits of the renunciate life should practice the same way.

The Buddha taught the meditation on the ugliness of the body, then left to go on retreat. However, many monks, misconstruing the teachings, ending up killing themselves. The Buddha taught breath meditation as a peaceful and pleasant abiding.
When the Buddha asks Venerable Kimbila about breath meditation, he is unable to answer. At Ānanda’s urging, the Buddha explains in detail.
The Buddha goes on a three month retreat, and later says that during that time he mostly practiced breath meditation.

Venerable Lomasavaṅgīsa explains to Mahānāma that the difference between a trainee and the Realized One is that the trainees practice to give up the hindrances, whereas the Realized One has already ended all defilements.
Answering Ānanda, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.
The Buddha explains to Ānanda how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.
Answering some mendicants, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.
The Buddha explains to some mendicants how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

sc_eng_sutta: Completely Understanding the Course of Time

sc_blurb: Even a universal monarch may have a bad rebirth, but someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is freed from such destinies.

sc_eng_sutta: The Culmination of the Spiritual Life
sc_blurb: Someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.

The lay follower Dīghāvu is ill and he asks for the Buddha to visit. Dīghāvu confirms that he possesses the four factors of stream-entry and in addition six contemplations leading to insight. Yet he is still worried that his father will miss him when he dies.

Sāriputta explains to Ānanda that someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.

The Buddha asks Sāriputta about the four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice. He also defines the “stream” and the “stream-enterer”.

After the rainy season, the chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa hear that the Buddha is approaching and go to see him. They describe their joy at knowing when the Buddha is approaching, and speak of their special duties guarding the royal harem. The Buddha says they have four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha; and here generosity rather than ethics as the final factor.

The brahmin householders of Bamboo Gate ask the Buddha how to live well in the home. The Buddha teaches them seven principles they can apply to themselves, which are practical applications of the Golden Rule. Someone with these seven principles and the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.

Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.

sc_eng_sutta: A Saṅgha of a Thousand Nuns
sc_blurb: The Buddha teaches a thousand nuns the four factors of stream-entry.
The Buddha contrasts a foolish brahmanical ritual called “going upwards” with the four factors of stream-entry.
Sāriputta asks Ānanda how many things are given up and how many things possessed by the stream-enterer.
A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.

sc_eng_sutta: Fear of the Bad Place, the Underworld
sc_blurb: A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.
You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.
You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.
Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.
Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.
The Buddha visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has long practiced the Dhamma.

Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has the four factors of stream-entry.
Mahānāma and Godhā the Sakyans discuss whether a stream-enterer has three or four factors. They go to the Buddha to settle it, and Mahānāma testifies to his faith.

When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.

When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.

When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Sāriputta reminds him of his considerable accomplishments in the Dhamma, analyzing stream-entry in ten factors, at which Anāthapiṇḍika recovers. Later he invited Sāriputta and Ānanda for a meal, and Sāriputta thanked him with verses.
When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Ānanda reminds him of the four factors of stream-entry, which Anāthapiṇḍika claims to possess.
A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.
A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.

The Buddha teaches the four factors of stream-entry to Nandaka, the minister of the Licchavis. When his servant tells him it is time for his ritual bath, he says that the inner bathing of the Dhamma is enough.
The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit.
The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit.
The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit.
The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods.
The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods, for the gods hold non-violence as supreme.
When a person possesses the four factors of stream-entry, the gods regard them as similar to themselves.
The Buddha explains to Mahānāma what is a lay follower, what is a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower accomplished in faith, generosity, and wisdom.
Like rain falling on the mountain top, the four factors of stream-entry flow on to the ending of defilements.
Kāḷigodhā the Sakyan lady confirms to the Buddha that she possesses the four factors of stream-entry.
Someone who completely lacks the four factors of stream-entry is an ordinary person. But even a stream-enterer may be negligent if they do not make further effort in meditation.
The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is said to be prosperous.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is said to be prosperous.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.
Four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice.
A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer. With verses.

When a monk comes from Sāvatthī to Kapilavatthu, the Sakyans visit him and ask as to the health of the Buddha and the Saṅgha. Then they ask what the monk has learned. He replies that the number of perfected ones is few, and those on lower levels of attainment are greater in number.

The lay follower Dhammadinna leads a group of 500 to visit the Buddha. He encourages them to study deep discourses, but they protest that they don’t have enough time. So the Buddha encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.

Mahānāma asks the Buddha how a lay follower should teach a wise lay follower who is ill. He should first be encouraged in the four factors of stream-entry, and then urged to let go of attachments, until he realizes full freedom.
Association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice lead to the fruit of stream-entry.
Mendicants should develop immersion so as to understand the four noble truths: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
Mendicants should develop seclusion so as to understand the four noble truths.
Members of good families go forth to understand the four noble truths.
Members of good families go forth to penetrate the four noble truths.
True ascetics understand the four noble truths.
True ascetics become awakened through understanding the four noble truths.
Don’t think bad thoughts. Instead, think of the four noble truths.
Don’t think in useless ways. Instead, reflect on the four noble truths.
Don’t argue. Instead, converse on the four noble truths.
Don’t gossip. Instead, talk about the four noble truths.

sc_eng_sutta: Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma
sc_blurb: The famous first discourse, taught at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics. It begins by rejecting the extremes of asceticism and indulgence and recommends the middle way of the eightfold path. Then it defines the four noble truths and analyzes them in twelve aspects. It ends with Venerable Kondañña becoming the first person apart from the Buddha to realize the Dhamma.
All Realized Ones understand the four noble truths in their twelve aspects.
The four noble truths are defined, with the five aggregates under the truth of suffering.
The four noble truths are defined, with the six sense fields under the truth of suffering.
The Buddha asks the mendicants how they remember the four noble truths.
The Buddha asks the mendicants how they remember the four noble truths.
Ignorance is not knowing the four noble truths.
Understanding is knowing the four noble truths.
Each of the four noble truths has innumerable implications.
Each of the four noble truths is real, not otherwise.
It is because of not understanding the four noble truths that both the Buddha and others have wandered for so long in transmigration. With verses.
True ascetics understand the four noble truths. With verses.
The Realized One is called the Buddha because he understands the four noble truths.
All Buddhas become awakened through the four noble truths.
Only by knowing and seeing the four noble truths are the defilements ended.
You should encourage your friends in the four noble truths.
The four noble truths is real, not otherwise, that is why they are noble.
In this world, the Realized One is the noble one, that is why the four truths are noble.
The first truth is to be understood; the second is to be given up; the third is to be realized; and the fourth is to be developed.

Some mendicants are discussing whether the four truths are necessarily seen together. Venerable Gavampati asserts that he has learned it from the Buddha that they are: if you see one, you see them all.
In a siṁsapā grove, the Buddha holds up a handful of leaves, and compares it to all the leaves in the forest. So too, he has taught the four noble truths, which is only a fraction of what he knows.
Just as it’s impossible to keep water in a basket of pine needles, it’s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.
Beings who have not seen the four noble truths roam on from one birth to another, like a stick thrown end to end.
Even more than if your clothes are on fire, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.
Even more than if you’re being tortured with spikes, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.
The small creatures in the ocean are greater in number than all the foliage in the jungles of India. Still, your rebirths are more than this.
As the dawn precedes the sunrise, right view precedes the penetration of the four noble truths.
As long as there are no sun and moon, the world is in darkness. So too, as long as the Realized One has not arisen and declared the four noble truths, the world is in darkness.
One who has not seen the four noble truths is as feeble as a tuft of cotton wool, while one who has seen them is like a deep-rooted pillar.
No-one can refute you if you are well grounded in the four noble truths.

The Buddha tells the curious tale of a man who sat by a lotus pond to speculate about the world, and saw an army enter a lotus stalk. He thought he was going mad. The Buddha said that no, the army was real. Nevertheless, you should not speculate about such things, but should reflect on the four noble truths.
The Buddha takes the mendicants to a steep precipice, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still deeper precipice.
The Buddha speaks of a hell called the great inferno, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still fiercer inferno.
Just as it’s impossible to climb the upper floor without building the lower floors first, it’s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.
Ānanda sees Licchavi youths shoot arrows through keyholes. But seeing the four noble truths is even harder.
Interstellar space is dark and empty; but not seeing the four noble truths is even worse.
A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.
A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.
As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a bit of dirt under a nail compared to the whole earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a drop of water on a blade of grass compared to a massive dam, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few drops of water compared to the confluence of great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few drops of water compared to confluence of the great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few jujube seeds compared to the great earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few jujube seeds compared to the great earth, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few drops of water compared to the ocean, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As a few drops of water compared to the ocean, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As seven bits of gravel are smaller than the Himalayas, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
As seven bits of gravel are smaller than the Himalayas, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
