This is a ghost sutta: there is no text for it in any available editions. However, the summary verse at the end of the chapter (AN 4.110) mentions “two on mangoes”. The commentary notes the existence of a discourse here, but merely says that its meaning is clear. A note in the VRI edition says that there is a reading that has obhāsa where the previous sutta has vaṇṇa.

sc_eng_sutta: Things That Play a Part in Realization
sc_blurb: Six kinds of perception that lead to wisdom.
If a mendicant nurses six kinds of defilements it leads to bitterness and disputes in the Saṅgha.
Seeing the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī preparing a meal for the Saṅgha, the Buddha celebrated by saying that giving is of great benefit when the donor and the recipient each possess three qualities.
The Buddha rebuts a brahmin’s claim that there is no such thing as actions initiated by oneself.
Greed, hate, and delusion are the roots of deeds.
The Buddha explains to Venerable Kimbila the reasons why Buddhism lasts long after the Buddha’s demise.
Even a simple block of wood can be perceived in different ways by a mendicant with advanced meditation.
When visited by a noisy crowd, the Buddha speaks to his attendant Nāgita of his love of seclusion and solitude, and of his regard for forest mendicants.
When going for a bath, the Buddha encounters a giant royal elephant. But a spiritual giant is even more impressive.
In response to criticism, the Buddha explains that it is difficult to compare the spiritual development of different individuals, so we should not be judgmental.
Poor people suffer when they get in debt. Spiritual practitioners who are devoid of good qualities suffer in a similar way.

In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Mahācunda urges different groups of meditators, whether they emphasize serenity or insight, to respect and support each other.
The Buddha explains to the wanderer Moliyasīvaka how the teaching may be realized in the present life.
The Buddha explains a brahmin how the teaching may be realized in the present life.

Two monks separately come to the Buddha and speak of awakening in terms of letting go conceit. The Buddha affirms that they are, in fact, awakened, and that such indirect means are the proper way to make such declarations.
Just as a tree without leaves cannot grow, sense restraint is the foundation for spiritual growth.
Venerables Ānanda and Sāriputta discuss how a mendicant can further their learning and understanding.
The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇī the ambition, quest, commitment, insistence, and ultimate goal of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, women, bandits, and ascetics.
With a series of vivid similes, the Buddha shows how diligence leads to benefits in both this life and the next.

The monk Dhammika annoys both the monks and the layfolk so badly that they banish him. He comes to the Buddha, who consoles him and raises his spirits with a story, while at the same time showing him the error of his ways.
When Venerable Soṇa thinks of disrobing, the Buddha comes and encourages him with the famous simile of the lute that is tuned neither too loose nor too tight.
The Buddha consoles Venerable Phagguṇa on his deathbed, and he dies at peace. The Buddha then explains to Ānanda the benefits of hearing the Dhamma at the right time.

Ānanda asks the Buddha about the six classes of people described by the rival ascetic Pūraṇa Kassapa. The Buddha rejects them, and proposes an alternate scheme, emphasizing the importance ones deeds in this life.
The Buddha explains diverse methods for overcoming diverse kinds of defilements.
The householder Dārukammika claims to give gifts to arahants. But the Buddha warns him that it’s hard to know who is really an arahant, and encourage him instead to make offerings to the Saṅgha.

The junior monk Citta Hatthisāriputta rudely interrupts his seniors, and is admonished by Mahākoṭṭhita. His friends speak in his defense, but Mahākoṭṭhita warns them with a long explanation of how hard it is to know another’s mind. Ultimately, Citta disrobes.

Several senior mendicants discuss the “Questions of Metteyya” from the Pārāyana (Snp 5.3). Each propose an interpretation, and they then ask the Buddha. He praises each reading, but gives his own intended meaning.

sc_eng_sutta: Knowledge of the Faculties of Persons
sc_blurb: A monk asks whether, when the Buddha said that Devadatta was going to hell, he was speaking metaphorically. The Buddha castigates him, wondering how anyone could misunderstand such a straightforward statement, and explains how he reads the minds of others and understands where their deeds will lead them.
A detailed analysis of several central themes, including sense perception, feeling, defilements, kamma, etc.
The Buddha possesses six spiritual powers that enable him to roar his lion’s roar.
Six things lead to non-return.
Six things lead to perfection.
With bad friends, a mendicant cannot fulfill six good qualities, but with good friends they can.
A mendicant who loves to socialize can’t find peace in meditation, but one who loves solitude can.

Without samādhi or immersion it is impossible to realize the higher truths of the path.

Qualities for realizing arahantship.

Qualities leading to happiness.

Possessing six qualities a mendicant attains to greatness.

Things leading to hell or heaven.
Things leading to or obstructing the attainment of perfection.
Things leading to growth or deterioration by day or night.
Possessing six qualities a mendicant attains to coolness.
Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.
Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.
Things that enable or obstruct true understanding while listening to the teachings.
Requirements for becoming a stream-enterer.
Things given up by a stream-enterer.
Things impossible for a stream-enterer.
Things impossible for a stream-enterer.
Things impossible for a stream-enterer.
Things impossible for a stream-enterer.
Things impossible for a stream-enterer.
Things rare to find in the world.
Benefits of stream-entry.
A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as permanent.
A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as pleasurable.
A mendicant on the path cannot see any thing as not-self.
A mendicant on the path cannot see extinguishment as suffering.
Reasons for meditating on impermanence.
Reasons for meditating on suffering.
Reasons for meditating on not-self.
Giving up rebirth in the three realms of existence, and developing the three trainings.
Giving up conceit and craving.
Antidotes for greed, hate, and delusion.
Antidotes for bad conduct.
Antidotes for bad thoughts.
Antidotes for harmful perceptions.
Antidotes for harmful properties.
Antidotes for views of gratification, self, and wrong views.
Antidotes for discontent, cruelty, and misconduct.
Antidotes for discontent, unawareness, and desire.
Antidotes for being hard to correct, bad friendship, and distraction.
Antidotes for restlessness, lack of restraint, and heedlessness.
Things that enable or obstruct meditation on the body.
Things that enable or obstruct meditation on various things.
Possessing six qualities, the householder Tapussa sees the Dhamma.
Possessing six qualities, various householders see the Dhamma.
Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.
Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.
The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike spiritual wealth.
The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, envy, and stinginess.
The underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
Factors that make a family worth visiting.
Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
Seven people found in the world who are like those in water.
Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
A mendicant with seven qualities is qualified to graduate.
The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the Licchavis at the Sārandada shrine near Vesālī.

King Ajātasattu of Magadha wishes to invade the Vajjians, and sends his minister Vassakāra to tell the Buddha of his intentions. The Buddha recalls the time he taught the seven principles of non-decline to the Vajjians.
The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
Seven qualities leading to the decline of a mendicant who is a trainee.
Seven qualities leading to the decline of a lay follower.
Seven failures for a lay follower.
Seven ruins for a lay follower.
A god speaks of the the seven principles of non-decline to the Buddha, who repeats it to the mendicants.
The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.
The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.
The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god. Sāriputta offers additional explanation.
When a friend has seven factors, one should associate with them.
When a mendicant has seven factors, one should stay close to them even if they send you away.
With seven qualities, a mendicant will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis.
With seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis.
Seven qualities leading to mastery of meditation.
With seven qualities, Sāriputta became a master of meditation.

Sāriputta visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.

Ānanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.
Seven planes of consciousness in which beings may be reborn.
The path factors are the prerequisite for right immersion.
Seven fires, some physical, some psychological.
The brahmin Uggatasarīra has arranged a great sacrifice. On Ānanda’s advice, he asks the Buddha how to make a sacrifice beneficial.
Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in brief.
Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in detail.
The brahmin Jāṇussoṇī asks the Buddha about behaviors that are a blemish to the celibate life.
By focusing on their own gendered attributes, a man or woman becomes attached to them and develops lust for the opposite sex.
The lay followers of Campā seek a teaching from the Buddha. Together with Sāriputta, they ask the Buddha about what makes a gift fruitful.

Sāriputta and Moggallāna are on tour in the southern hills. A deity informs the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī that they are approaching. When Sāriputta expresses his amazement that she speaks with the gods, she goes on to list many other of her own amazing qualities.
The Buddha explains why a noble disciple has no doubt when it comes to the unexplained points.
Seven kinds of rebirth for non-returners, as well as extinguishment by not grasping.
Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture’s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggallāna interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.
The Buddha explains the benefits of giving that are visible in the present life, and one that is only apparent in the next.
Four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.
Venerable Kimbila asks the Buddha the reasons for the long-lasting of Buddhism after the Buddha’s demise.
Qualities required for arahantship.
Before his awakening, Moggallāna is struggling with sleepiness in meditation. The Buddha visits him and gives seven ways to dispel drowsiness, and other important teachings.
The incalculable benefits of merit that last for many aeons.
Anāthapiṇḍika’s home was in an uproar due to the badly behaved Sujātā, newly wedded to one of his sons. The Buddha speaks to her on the different kinds of wives.
When someone is angry, they wish ill upon their enemy, and are disappointed if they do well. This sutta includes a powerful set of verses.
A sense of conscience is the foundation that leads step by step to liberation.
A rare discourse on cosmic evolution. The Buddha describes the successive appearance of seven suns and how even the earth will be burned up.

When a king’s fortress is well supplied with seven things and has four kinds of food supplies it is impregnable. Similarly, a noble disciple with seven qualities and the four absorptions is impregnable.
A mendicant who has seven qualities is worthy, with a special emphasis on listening to and learning the teaching.
The blossoming of the Shady Orchid Tree delights the gods of the Thirty-Three, and in the same way, the renunciation of a Buddhist ascetic is delightful.
Sāriputta reflects on what a mendicant should revere in order to develop the wholesome. He reports to the Buddha that these things are indeed found in himself.
Liberation doesn’t happen because you wish for it, but because you develop the path.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Great Mass of Fire
sc_blurb: It would be better for a monk to embrace a blazing fire than to lie with a maiden.
There have been many great teachers in the past, who should not be reviled. But reviling a single noble disciple is even more serious.
Araka was a famous teacher long ago, when the life span was much greater than today. Nevertheless, he still taught impermanence; how much more is it relevant today!

sc_eng_sutta: An Expert in the Monastic Law (1st)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: An Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: An Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: An Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (1st)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)
sc_blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.
The Buddha teaches the Vinaya expert Upāli a short summary of the teaching.
Seven principles for settling issues and disputes that have arisen in the community.
A mendicant destroys seven defilements.
An ascetic  destroys seven defilements.
A brahmin destroys seven defilements.
A scholar destroys seven defilements.
A bathed initiate destroys seven defilements.
A knowledge master destroys seven defilements.
A noble one destroys seven defilements.
A perfected one destroys seven defilements.
Seven bad qualities starting with faithlessness.
Seven good qualities starting with faith.
Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing impermanence in the eye.

sc_eng_sutta: Observing Suffering in the Eye, Etc.
sc_blurb: Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing suffering, etc., in the eye, etc.
Develop insight into greed through the awakening factors.
Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with impermanence.
Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with ugliness.
Develop complete understanding, etc., of greed.
Develop complete understanding, etc., of hate, etc.
The eight benefits of practicing the meditation on love.
Eight conditions that lead to the arising of wisdom, its growth and perfection.
Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.
Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.
The eight worldly conditions in brief: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.
The eight worldly conditions in detail: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.
Devadatta’s downfall was the eight worldly conditions.

In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Uttara, staying in a distant land, teaches that a mendicant should review their own failings and those of others. Questioned by Sakka, the Lord of Gods, Uttara affirms that he learned this from the Buddha.
The Buddha praises the grace and restraint of Venerable Nanda.

When a certain monk was admonished, he responded by attacking his reprovers. The Buddha tells the other monks to expel him, explaining that when such a monk lives hidden in the Saṅgha, his corruption can spread to the other monks.

The brahmin Verañja rebukes the Buddha for his lack of respect for senior brahmins. He levels a series of criticisms, each of which the Buddha deflects by redefining terms. The Buddha affirms that his claim to superiority is because he was the first to achieve awakening.

General Sīha, a prominent disciple of the Jains, visits the Buddha against the wishes of Mahāvīra, the Jain leader. He challenges the Buddha by bringing up the various ways that people criticize him. Convinced by the Buddha’s response, Sīha wishes to take refuge in the Buddha; but the Buddha urges him to be cautious and to continue supporting the Jains.
With eight qualities a royal thoroughbred is worthy of a king. Likewise, with eight qualities a mendicant is worthy.
Eight flaws in wild horses, similar to eight flaws in mendicants.
Eight different kinds of stain.
A mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of being sent on a mission.
A woman imprisons a man in eight ways.
A man imprisons a woman in eight ways.
Demons delight in the ocean for eight reasons, and likewise the mendicants delight in the Dhamma for eight reasons.
On a full-moon night, the Buddha was to recite the code of conduct for the monks. However, he remained silent until dawn, due to the presence of a corrupt monk.
The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Vesālī. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.
The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.

The Buddha celebrates the seven amazing qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he hears of this, Hatthaka is anxious to know that no lay people were present. Learning of this, the Buddha adds humility as an eight quality.
The Buddha learns from Hatthaka of Āḷavī how he maintains a large following. He then celebrates Hatthaka’s eight good qualities.
Questioned by his relative Mahānāma, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.
Questioned by Jīvaka Komārabhacca, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.
Eight very different kinds of powers.
Eight powers of a perfected one.
Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.

Venerable Anuruddha reflects that the teachings is for someone who is of few wishes, content, secluded, energetic, mindful, peaceful, and wise. To these seven thoughts, the Buddha adds an eighth: the teaching is for those who delight in non-proliferation. Practicing in line with these eight thoughts of a great man, Venerable Anuruddha achieves perfection.
Eight ways of giving a gift.
This verse on qualities of a good person appears to be a fragment of text, perhaps originally part of the previous sutta.
Eight grounds for giving.
The rewards of giving are compared to fields of different qualities.
When giving, if you expect a certain result in the next life, you can get it, if the conditions are right.
The good deeds of giving, ethics, and meditation lead to good rebirths, depending on the level to which they are developed.
A good person gives gifts in eight ways.
When a good person is born, it benefits eight kinds of people, like a rain-cloud showering all over the land.
Eight streams of merit, consisting in going for refuge and five kinds of gifts.
Eight kinds of misdeed are conducive to bad outcomes.

sc_eng_sutta: The Sabbath With Eight Factors, In Brief
sc_blurb: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Such a sabbath is glorious.

sc_eng_sutta: The Sabbath With Eight Factors, In Detail
sc_blurb: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. The benefits are explained at length.
The Buddha teaches the wealthy laywoman Visākhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones.

The Buddha teaches the layman Vāseṭṭha that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Vāseṭṭha exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.

The Buddha teaches the laywoman Bojjhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Bojjhā exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.
Some “Agreeable” gods put on a display of music and dance for Venerable Anuruddha, but he is not impressed. He then asks the Buddha how women are reborn in such a heaven.

sc_eng_sutta: With Visākhā on the Agreeable Gods
sc_blurb: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.

sc_eng_sutta: With Nakula’s Mother on the Agreeable Gods
sc_blurb: The Buddha teaches the housewife Nakulamātā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.
The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.
The Buddha teaches the mendicants four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.
Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī, the Buddha’s foster mother, requests ordination from the Buddha. He declines, until urged to relent by Ānanda. He allows Mahāpajāpatī to go forth on eight conditions.
With eight qualities a monk may be appointed to teach the nuns.
Mahāpajāpatī wishes to go on retreat, so the Buddha teaches her eight principles that summarize the Dhamma in brief.

Dīghajāṇu of the Koliyans asks the Buddha to teach in a way suitable for lay people who enjoy life. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.
The brahmin Ujjaya is going abroad, and asks the Buddha to teach him. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.
The Buddha explains how addiction to sensual pleasures is perilous.

sc_eng_sutta: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods (1st)
sc_blurb: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.

sc_eng_sutta: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods (2nd)
sc_blurb: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.
Eight kinds of person are worthy.
Eight kinds of person are worthy.
The Buddha describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.
Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others.
A monk asks for teachings before going on retreat, but the Buddha rebukes him, as he has not practiced sincerely. Nevertheless, he persists, and the Buddha teaches him meditation in detail.
At Gayā, the Buddha describes his meditation before awakening. He was able to see lights and forms, converse with gods, and understand the deeds that made them gods.
Eight dimensions of meditative mastery, based on the vision of certain shapes and colors.
Eight meditative liberations, based on the vision of forms and the attainment of the formless.
Eight kinds of ignoble statement that misrepresent the truth.
Eight kinds of noble statement that convey the truth.
Eight kinds of assemblies: aristocrats, brahmins, householders, ascetics, and various deities. The Buddha has visited each of these in disguise.
When the Buddha gives up his life-force, an earthquake is felt. The Buddha explains to Ānanda the eight causes of earthquakes.
Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.
Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.
Various mendicants practice mindfulness of death, but do so inadequately. The Buddha explains how to do so with proper urgency,
A mendicant should reflect each night on the dangers that lie around them, and practice mindfulness of death with urgency to give up the unwholesome.
Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual.
Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual, in detail.
Sāriputta describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.
Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others, explained by Sāriputta.
Eight conditions for the decline or success of a trainee mendicant.

sc_eng_sutta: Grounds for Laziness and Arousing Energy
sc_blurb: Eight grounds for laziness, and the corresponding eight grounds for energy.
Mindfulness and situational awareness are a foundation for developing higher spiritual qualities leading to liberation.
Venerable Puṇṇiya asks the Buddha why he sometimes feels like teaching and other times doesn’t.
The root of all things, and other factors that apply to all things.
The Buddha teaches how to be a success as a master thief. Unusually, this discourse has no “spiritual” counterpart, so it sounds like the Buddha just giving a lesson in thievery!
Different titles for the Buddha.

When the householders of Icchānaṅgala make a racket in the monastery, the Buddha asks his attendant Nāgita what is going on. The Buddha speaks strongly of his dislike for material gains, and his love of seclusion.
Eight reasons the Saṅgha may overturn the bowl against a lay follower.
Eight reasons the lay followers may declare no confidence or confidence regarding a mendicant.
Eight reasons the lay followers may enjoin an act of reconciliation on a mendicant, or relax said act.

sc_eng_sutta: Proper Behavior in a Case of Aggravated Misconduct
sc_blurb: Eight things a mendicant charged with aggravated misconduct must observe.

sc_eng_sutta: Untitled Discourses With Various Laywomen on the Sabbath

sc_blurb: Beginning with good friendship, the Buddha teaches nine things that give rise to the qualities that lead to awakening.
The things that a mendicant relies on as supports in spiritual practice.

Venerable Meghiya, while attending on the Buddha, wants to go off and meditate in a forest alone. The Buddha discourages him, but he goes anyway. When his meditation doesn’t go well, he returns chastened to the Buddha, who teaches him about the benefits of good companions and other fundamentals of a balanced spiritual practice.

Nandaka is teaching the monks when the Buddha arrives. Unbeknown to those inside, the Buddha waits until the talk was finished, then enters. Nandaka is embarrassed at keeping the Buddha waiting, but the Buddha praises him and offers a teaching on the four things a mendicant should complete. Nandaka then teaches five benefits of listening to Dhamma.
A noble disciple who develops four powers overcomes five fears.
Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.
The wanderer Sutavā asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine.
The wanderer Sajjha asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine, which differ slightly from AN 9.7.
Nine kinds of persons: the eight noble persons and the ordinary person.

sc_eng_sutta: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods
sc_blurb: Nine persons are worthy of gifts: the eight noble persons and a member of the spiritual family.

After the rains season, Sāriputta takes leave of the Buddha. Another monk falsely accuses Sāriputta of hitting him before leaving. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to answer the accusation. Before the Saṅgha, Sāriputta denies it, uttering a powerful statement of spiritual prowess.

Sāriputta visits some wanderers, who claim that only perfected ones are free from bad rebirth. Sāriputta has no opinion on this, but asks the Buddha, who replies that even stream-enterers are freed from lower rebirth.
Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the spiritual path is for the purpose of changing the results of deeds.
Sāriputta questions Venerable Samiddhi on the basis of intentions and thoughts.
The body is compared to a boil with nine orifices.
Nine perceptions to be developed in meditation.
Nine factors in how a family relates to the Saṅgha.
Nine factors for a glorious sabbath: the eight precepts and the meditation on love.
Some deities come to the Buddha and speak of how their practice in their past life was limited and unsatisfactory.

The wealthy and devoted lay supporter Anāthapiṇḍika rather curiously says that only poor alms are given in his home. The Buddha praises gracious and bounteous generosity. But meditation surpasses even the greatest offering.
A comparison of the people of India, of Uttarakuru, and of the heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Nine kinds of horses are compared with nine kinds of monks.
Nine things that are rooted in craving.
Nine realms into which sentient beings may be reborn.
Nine reflections by which a mendicant knows their mind has wisdom.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Stone Pillar
sc_blurb: Venerables Candikāputta and Sāriputta differ in their interpretation of a teaching proposed by the notorious schismatic Devadatta.
A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.
A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.
Nine grounds for resentment.
Nine ways of removing resentment.
Nine meditative states, each of which arises from the cessation of something present in the previous state.
Nine progressive meditation states.
Nine progressive meditation states, explained in detail.
Sāriputta declares that extinguishment is bliss, precisely because nothing is felt there. He explains this apparent paradox with reference to the nine progressive meditations.
Just as a foolish cow can get in trouble wandering the mountains, a foolish mendicant can get lost practicing absorption if they do it wrongly.
The ending of defilements happens due to the practice of absorption meditation.

Ānanda exclaims how amazing it is that the Buddha has found a way to freedom while still experiencing the world. Questioned by the monk Udāyī, Ānanda recounts a discussion on advanced meditation with the nun Jaṭilagāhiyā.

Two brahmin cosmologists ask the Buddha to decide between competing claims as to whether the cosmos is infinite. Rejecting metaphysical claims, the Buddha says that there is no end of the world that can be reached by traveling; but without reaching the end of the world you can’t be free of suffering.

sc_eng_sutta: The War Between the Gods and the Titans
sc_blurb: In the wars between gods and demons, they find safety only in their own fortress. Similarly, a mendicant finds safety in absorption.

sc_eng_sutta: The Simile of the Bull Elephant in the Forest
sc_blurb: A bull elephant, annoyed by living in the herd, goes off by himself. Similarly, a mendicant feeling crowded in a monastery goes off by themselves and happily meditates in seclusion.
The householder Tapussa reflects that it is renunciation that distinguishes lay from monastic. The Buddha responds by giving a long account of his practice of absorption before awakening.
At Udāyī’s request, Ānanda explains an obscure verse spoken (in SN 2.7) by a deity. The nine progressive meditations are the escape from confinement.
The Buddha speaks of a “direct witness’, that is, someone who personally has thorough and proficient experience of the different meditation states.
One liberated by wisdom first enters the meditation states, then understands them.
One freed both ways is both proficient in and understands the meditation states.
The teaching apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.

sc_eng_sutta: Extinguishment Is Apparent in the Present Life
sc_blurb: Extinguishment apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.

sc_eng_sutta: Weaknesses in Training and Mindfulness Meditation
Weaknesses in Training and the Bases of Psychic Power

sc_blurb: The purpose of ethics, leading step by step to liberation.
There’s no need to make a wish to get enlightened; it happens naturally when the conditions are there.
The Buddha teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
Sāriputta teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
Ānanda teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
Ānanda asks the Buddha about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious.

Ānanda asks Sāriputta about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious. Sāriputta confirms that there is, and claims to have attained it.
Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

sc_eng_sutta: Inspiring All Around: the Peaceful Liberations
sc_blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

sc_eng_sutta: Inspiring All Around: the Three Knowledges
sc_blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.
Five factors that a mendicant should have, and five factors of a lodging that they should occupy.
A mendicant should abandon the five hindrances and possess the five factors of the adept.
Five lower and five higher fetters.
Five kinds of emotional barrenness and five emotional shackles.
Diligence is the foremost of all good qualities.

sc_eng_sutta: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods
sc_blurb: Ten persons who are worthy.
Ten qualities that serve as protector.
Ten qualities that serve as protector, in detail.
Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide.
Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide, in detail.
Like a lion, a Realized One roars his preeminence based on ten powers.
The Buddha claims to be assured regarding the various different doctrinal hypotheses, based on the ten powers.
Some things are to be given by body, others by speech, and still others by wisdom.
Venerable Mahācunda teaches that, though a mendicant might claim to be free of greed, hate, and delusion, this is not always the case.
Ten universal dimensions of meditation, or kasiṇas.

The female lay follower Kāḷī of Kuraraghara in Avantī asks Venerable Mahākaccāna about a verse spoken by the Buddha in “The Maidens’ Questions” (SN 4.25). He replies in terms of the ten universal dimensions of meditation.
Some wanderers claim to teach the direct knowledge of all things, just like the Buddha. However the Buddha disputes this by presenting ten “Great Questions” that they cannot answer.
Some lay people ask the nun from Kajaṅgalā regarding the ten “Great Questions”. Though she has not heard this teaching herself, she explains from her own understanding, and is praised by the Buddha.

Starting with a comparison with the King of Kosala, the Buddha teaches a series of ten advanced teachings. He culminates by affirming that he teaches the full understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.
King Pasenadi returns victorious from battle and immediately goes to see the Buddha, bowing reverentially to his feet, and declaring ten reasons for his love and devotion to the Buddha.
The Buddha teaches Venerable Upāli the ten reasons for establishing the training rules.

sc_blurb: Ten reasons for suspending the recitation of the code of conduct.
Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be appointed to judge a dispute.
Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give ordination.
Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give dependence.
Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be attended by a novice.
Ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha.
Ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha.

The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of creating harmony.

Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.
Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.

Mahāli the Licchavi asks the Buddha for the causes of bad deeds.

sc_eng_sutta: Ten Regular Reflections for a Renunciate

Ten things that depend on the body.

Sāriputta teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.
The Buddha doesn’t praise stagnation in wholesome qualities, let alone decline.

Sāriputta explains what the Buddha meant by a mendicant who is in decline.
Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.
Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.
The root of all things, and similar principles.
Ten reflections that strengthen the mind of a renunciate.
The monk Girimānanda is sick. The Buddha encourages Ānanda to visit him and speak of ten perceptions.
Even though ignorance has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.
Even though craving has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.

At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.
At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.
The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten topics of conversation suitable for mendicants.
The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten grounds of praise.

When the Buddha receives noisy visitors, several monks withdraw to a nearby forest to meditate. The Buddha praises them, saying that noise is a thorn to absorption.
Ten desirable things that are hard to get.
Ten aspects of prosperity.

The female lay disciple Migasālā questions Ānanda how the Buddha could have declared her father and her uncle had the same level of spiritual attainment, when one was much more strict than the other. Ānanda conveys this to the Buddha, who responds that only such as he can pass judgment, since the spiritual faculties of individuals are complex and hard to understand.
Without rebirth, old age, and death, there would be no teaching of Dhamma. The Buddha teaches a series of sets of three things leading to liberation.
A bad monk has ten bad qualities, like a crow.
Jain ascetics have ten bad qualities.
Ten ground for resentment.
Ten ways of removing resentment.
Giving up ten things, the Buddha lives free of limits.
A mendicant cannot achieve progress if they have ten bad qualities starting with lack of faith.
Venerable Puṇṇiya asks why the Buddha sometimes feels like teaching, other times not.
When a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
Venerable Mahācunda teaches that when a mendicant boasts about spiritual attainments, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
Venerable Mahākassapa teaches that when a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
The Buddha, speaking in reference to the monk Kalandaka, explains ten qualities that lead to discord or unity.
A mendicant who insults their spiritual companions incurs ten disasters.
The monk Kokālika accuses Sāriputta and Moggallāna of having evil wishes. The Buddha defends them. Later, Kokālika suffers calamity and is reborn in hell.

sc_eng_sutta: The Powers of One Who has Ended Defilements
sc_blurb: Ten powers by which a mendicant knows that they have ended the defilements.
The Buddha teaches Anāthapiṇḍika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.
A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.

Anāthapiṇḍika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha’s views. Anāthapiṇḍika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.

The householder Vajjiyamāhita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyamāhita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.

The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. Uttiya goes on to ask whether all beings will be liberated. The Buddha is silent, and Ānanda answers on his behalf.
The wanderer Kokanada meets Ānanda at the baths and engages him on the topic of the ten metaphysical questions.

sc_eng_sutta: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods
sc_blurb: With ten qualities, a mendicant is worthy.
With ten qualities, a senior mendicant is at ease wherever they live.

When Upāli asks to go into retreat, the Buddha warns him that secluded wilderness dwellings are hard to endure unless one is accomplished in meditation. He gives a long account of the training required before going into solitude, and ends by encouraging Upāli to stay in the Saṅgha.
Ten things must be given up before attaining perfection.
Three ascetic perceptions lead to seven results.
The seven factors of awakening lead to realizing the three knowledges.
The tenfold wrong path leads to failure, the tenfold right path leads to success.
When a person has wrong view, all their path development is wrong. But when they have right view, everything good follows.
Ignorance is the precursor of wrong view and the other bad qualities, while right view is the opposite.
Each of the ten path factors wears away its opposite.
The Buddha speaks of a southern land called “Bath”, but says that a spiritual bath is better.
The Buddha speaks of a purgative for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual purgative is better.
The Buddha speaks of a emetic for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual emetic is better.
The ten path factors each expel their opposite.
An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.
An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.
One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.
One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.
One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Ānanda.
The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.
The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.
The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.
As the dawn is the forerunner of the sunrise, right view is the forerunner of the path.
The ten path factors lead to the end of the defilements.

The Teaching of the True Persons

Through the teaching one may avoid the various kinds of bad deeds.
Cunda the smith tells the Buddha of rites of purification practiced by the western brahmins. The Buddha explains purification in his teaching.
Jāṇussoṇī describes brahmanical memorial rites for the dead, and asks if sharing merit actually benefits dead relatives. The Buddha replies that it might do in some circumstances.

sc_blurb: The ten kinds of bad deeds lead you to hell; the ten good deeds to heaven.
Those who do the ten kinds of bad deeds are like creepy creatures.
The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.
The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.
The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. If one develops the heart’s release through love, no bad deeds can persist there.
The Buddha teaches a brahmin that bad conduct leads to hell, good conduct to heaven.

sc_blurb: Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.

The Buddha teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.
Sāriputta teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists. Ānanda puts the same question to Sāriputta, and gets the same answer.
Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal attention has ceased, but there is still attention. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists.
The Buddha tells Venerable Sandha to meditate like a trained thoroughbred, not like a wild colt. Doing so, they may attain a deep state.
Possessing various sets of qualities, a mendicant is best among gods and men.
Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.
Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.
Nandiya the Sakiyan moves to Sāvatthī to be near the Buddha. At the end of the rains, he asks the Buddha’s advice on how to live.
Venerable Subhūti brings the young monk Saddha to meet the Buddha. The Buddha goes on to teach the manifestations of faith.
The meditation on love has eleven benefits.
Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.
A cowherd with eleven qualities is competent to look after a herd of cattle. Likewise, a mendicant with eleven qualities can grow in the Dhamma.

Ven. Ānanda comments on how the Buddha’s mother died shortly after his birth.

“Acts of merit” is a synonym for what is blissful, desirable, pleasing, endearing, charming. The Buddha recalls the results he himself has experienced from doing meritorious deeds.
Heedfulness with regard to skillful qualities keeps both kinds of benefit secure: benefit in this live and benefit in lives to come.
In this course of transmigrating, one person would leave behind a heap of bones as large as a mountain—if there were someone to collect the bones and the collection were not destroyed.

How brahmans, through greed, abandoned the good principles of their ancestors.
A good teacher, like a good boatman, is one who knows firsthand how to cross to the further shore.
The attitudes and behavior that enable one best to learn and benefit from the Dhamma.
Get up! Don’t let the opportunity for practice pass you by.
Rāhula reflects on the teachings he received from his father, the Buddha.
Vaṅgīsa, the foremost poet among the Buddha’s disciples, praises the Buddha in verse.
The sort of person who, having gone forth, is fit to wander through the world.
The proper code of conduct for lay followers of the Dhamma.
The young Bodhisatta (Buddha-to-be), soon after leaving home, explains why he refuses King Bimbisāra’s offer of a position in his court.
Māra attempts to dissuade the Bodhisatta from his path.
Four characteristics of well-spoken speech.

sc_eng_sutta: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake
sc_blurb: A brahman questions the Buddha to see if the latter deserves to receive the cake resulting from his sacrifice.
What are the qualities of a recipient that produce the most merit from a gift?
A sutta dating from early in the Buddha’s teaching career. A wanderer, disappointed in the teachings he has received from other teachers, approaches the Buddha with his questions.
Sela the brahman praises the Buddha to see how the latter responds to praise.
Death and loss are inevitable, but grief is not.
Is one worthy of respect because of one’s birth, or because of one’s actions?

A follower of Devadatta slanders Ven. Sāriputta and Ven. Moggallāna and, after suffering a painful disease, falls into hell. The sutta then gives a graphic description of the sufferings awaiting him there.
A sutta in two parts. The first part gives an account of events soon after the birth of the Bodhisatta. The second part describes the way of the sage.
Not all dualities are misleading. This sutta teaches ways to contemplate the duality of the origination and cessation of stress and suffering so as to reach awakening.
The drawbacks of sensual desires.
Those who remain attached to the body, to sensuality, and to their sense of “mine” will have a hard time freeing themselves from fear of death and from further becoming.
Freedom isn’t to be found by boasting of your precepts and practices or by debating your views.
How to avoid the trap of letting go of one thing only to cling to something more subtle.
The conceit that comes from clinging to practices or views—even if they’re supreme—is a fetter preventing full freedom.
Life is short. Possessiveness brings grief. Freedom comes from abandoning any sense of “mine.”
The drawbacks of falling away from the celibate life.
The drawbacks of engaging in debates, for winners and losers alike.
Māgandiya offers the Buddha his daughter in marriage. The Buddha refuses and further subdues Māgandiya’s pride by describing a state of peace that Māgandiya doesn’t understand.
How to live at peace.
The Buddha is questioned on the source of quarrels and disputes, and on the highest level of spiritual attainment.

sc_eng_sutta: The Shorter Discourse on Arrayed For Battle
sc_blurb: If the truth is one, how should a person behave in a world where many different truths are taught?

sc_eng_sutta: The Longer Discourse on Arrayed for Battle
sc_blurb: How to maintain freedom in a world full of disputes.
The attitudes and behavior of a monk training for the sake of total release.

The Buddha speaks in poignant terms of the saṁvega that led him to leave the household life. He concludes with recommendations for practice and a description of the person who has attained the goal of true peace and security.
When a monk, disaffected with the world, takes up the life of seclusion, what fears should he overcome? What dangers should he beware of? How should he train to blow away the impurities in his heart?
A brahman teacher sends his students to the Buddha to see if the latter is truly awakened.
A brahman questions the Buddha about mindfulness, discernment, and the cessation of name-and-form.
Who in the world is truly contented, truly free, truly a great person?
Birth and aging can be overcome, not through sacrificial rituals, but through training the mind to go beyond perturbation.
How does one cross the flood of birth and old age, sorrow and grief?
How can one become freed of all doubt?
What support should one hold on to in order to cross over the flood of craving? Can an awakened person be described?
Who deserves to be called a sage? Who has crossed over birth and aging?
How do you cross over entanglements in the world?
How to recognize an emancipated person.
What is the island above the flood of the great danger of birth?
How does one abandon birth and aging?
Bhadrāvudha asks the Buddha: How did you come to know the Dhamma?
How to reach unbinding and bring consciousness to a halt.
How to develop insight after mastering the perception of nothingness.
How should one view the world so as to escape the king of Death?
Alarmed by the deterioration of his aging body, Piṅgiya asks the Buddha how to conquer birth and decay.

sc_eng_sutta: Homage to the Way to the Far Shore
sc_blurb: The questions and events are summarized.

sc_eng_sutta: Preserving the Way to the Far Shore
sc_blurb: Piṅgiya, after becoming a non-returner, explains to his former teacher his devotion to the Buddha.
Arahant Moggallana asks a deva about previous good karma.
Giving always gives results.
Even offering a simple thing to the Sangha can give great results.
Arahant Moggallana asks a deva how he received a throne made of beryl gemstones.
Offering a chair with a confident heart to those free from defilements will bring great happiness.
Arahant Moggallana asks a deva how she gained a golden roofed ship as her mansion.
Offering water to the Noble Sangha will bring much happiness.
A deva explains the merit accumulated when she offered water to a monk who had fallen.
A deva explains the merit accumulated when offering light so that others may see.
Even a small offering of sesame seeds to the Supreme Buddha brings much merit.
A deva explains the benefits of staying faithful to one’s spouse and being honest.
A deva explains how keeping the precepts and being a follower of the Supreme Buddha can bring happiness.
Giving just a single oil cake to the noble Sangha results in much merit.
A deva explains how offering a honey covered cake led her to the heavenly Nandana Park.
Living a restrained life, keeping the precepts, and being generous will only bring good results.
The wife of King Bimbisara, now a deva, explains her unshakable confidence in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.
God Sakka asks what merit helped a deva become as radiant as a Brahma.
Only those who do good, wholesome deeds are reborn in heaven.
A deva explains how she attained the fruit of once returner.
God Sakka asks Arahant Kassapa about a lady who offered alms to him.
The Supreme Buddha with utmost compassion helps a low caste woman before her death.
The Supreme Buddha asks a deva how she gained a rare tree near her heavenly mansion.
A deva explains how delighted she was to keep her precepts and give generously.
A deva explains her regret in not developing her mind further.
A deva explains the benefits of having unshakable faith in the Triple Gem.
One can gain much happiness by observing the precepts and giving alms to the Noble Sangha.
A deva explains how she gained a beautiful body.
Offering alms with a happy, pure, and calm mind can bring many benefits.
A deva explains the happiness gained from offering a single oil cake to Arahant Moggallana.
Offering even a small piece of sugar cane can bring much happiness.
A deva explains the happiness one can achieve by being a good wife, following precepts and restraining one’s self.
The daughters of God Sakka explain how they gained such happiness as devas.
Multiple devas discuss the what meritorious actions they did to gain happiness.
Devas discuss the importance of thinking about the Noble Sanga when giving alms instead of individual monks.
A deva explains the happiness he gained after offering flowers during the funeral of Arahant Sariputta.
Can offerings to the Supreme Buddha after his passing away still give good results?
Following the precepts, leading a restrained life, practicing generosity, and having faith can bring much happiness.
A deva explains the results of offering a garland of flowers to the Supreme Buddha.
A servant offers flowers to the Supreme Buddha and gains much happiness.
Devas who possess strong confidence in the Supreme Buddha outshine other devas.
A deva offers a pair of robes to the Buddha and gains much happiness.
Offering even a small lump of rice cake to the Supreme Buddha will bring much happiness.
A deva explains the happiness he gained from offering medicine to the Supreme Buddha.
Rejoicing at someone else’s meritorious deed can bring much happiness.
Arahant Moggallana asks four devas what meritorious actions they did to gain such radiant bodies.
What does one gain when offering a monastery to the order of monks?
God Sakka asks another deva what meritorious actions he did to gain happiness.
A deva explains the fruits of giving a small sugar cane to Arahant Moggallana.
A deva explains how worshiping and honoring monks can lead to much merit.
A deva tells the story of how she was on the verge of suicide when the compassionate Supreme Buddha helps her.
A deva explains of his animal past and how he came to have such powers.
When one is greedy, evil and doesn’t keep precepts, what awaits is only suffering.
The Supreme Buddha teaches a young boy about going for refuge and the precepts.
A deva explains the happiness she gained after offering crab soup to the Sangha.
A deva explains the importance of speaking good words and living with a clean mind.
Having confidence in the Supreme Buddha is enough to bring much happiness.
Having confidence in monks is enough to bear great fruit.
A deva explains how the result of giving is always greater.
Offering a needle to an Arahant brought much happiness to a deva.
A deva explains the results of offering eight flowers to the stupa of Kassapa Supreme Buddha.
A deva explains the benefits of following the 5 precepts.
A man questions a deva on how he gained a divine white elephant.
A prince near death learns Dhamma from an Arahant and changes his ways to attain a better rebirth.
A radiant, powerful deva explains how giving to the Supreme Buddha can bring powerful merits.
Generosity and confidence when giving alms will bring much happiness.
A deva explains giving with confident hearts to monks will bring wonderful results.
What happens when one offers fruits to noble monks?
Living generously and giving with confident hearts can bring about much happiness.
What are the results of offering food and lodgings to an Arahant?
A deva’s gains were bountiful after giving water to a thirsty monk.
A human who guarded a barley field explains how he became a deva.
Having confidence and offering food and drinks to Arahants results in many benefits.
A deva explains the fruit of offering food and drink to Arahants.
A deva explains the benefits of offering alms to monks.
What are the results of taking care of one’s parents and having confidence in monks?
A deva explains the results of taking care of one’s parents and having confidence in monks.
A deva explains his offerings and the fruits of his labor.
What are the results of building a monastery and offering it to the Supreme Buddha?
A deva explains his encounter with Arahant Sāriputta and the meritorious actions he did to achieve happiness.
A deva explains how the compassion of Arahant Moggallana gave him much happiness.
What happened to, Kanthaka, the horse, who carried Prince Siddhartha on the day he left his home?
A deva explains how worshiping the relics of a Buddha can bring much happiness.
A deva shows a grieving father the way to end his sorrow through Dhamma.
A deva named Serissaka explains how he came to enjoy a comfortable life and what we can do to achieve the same.
Arahant Moggallana asks what meritorious action a deva did to became so powerful.
Arahants are like a field where we can plant offerings.
Even using harsh speech is enough to cause suffering.
A ghost explains the danger of using harsh speech.
How do we help our departed relatives?
The Supreme Buddha explains how to share merit with past relatives.
A ghost explains her suffering due to lying and evil deeds from a previous life.
Jealousy and hatred can only lead to suffering.
How do we help those who are stricken with grief?
What happens when you insult those who give?
A ghost explains the value of giving and sharing merit.
Why is important to give when we have the opportunity?
Is it possible to not be sad when someone dies? It is for noble disciples of the Supreme Buddha.
What could happen if we don’t give and are greedy?
How can we reduce our past relatives’ suffering?
Even minor evil actions can result in immense suffering.
Harsh speech and evil actions only brings negative results.
What should we do to secure happiness in our next life?
How should we think to overcome grief?
What can happen if we don’t give and insult those who do?
Why should we share merit with our past relatives?
Giving will always bring good results.
Harsh speech against those who do good result in suffering.
Even a small action can bring immense merit.
A ghost explains the severity of sexual misconduct.
An ascetic consoles Queen Ubbari and extinguishes her grief.
Generosity will lead to happiness and good results.
A ghost reveals how to share merit with his past relatives.
A ghost explains how to direct merit towards a good destination.
Greed and deceit only brings pain and suffering.
How does one escape from their evil past?
What happens when you let greed cloud your judgement?
Keeping precepts even for a small duration will provide benefits.
Taking the life of another will only lead to suffering.
What are the dangers of lying, gossip and divisive speech?
Insulting those who worship the Buddha’s relics will only bring suffering.
How does one escape from the path leading to hell?
A deva explains the results of good actions and following precepts to a group of merchants lost in the desert.
A ghost advises a king on the dangers of wrong views and the importance of taking refuge in the Triple Gem.
Two hell wardens explain to Revati the results of her evil deeds and show her the results of her husband’s merit.
A monk explains to a ghost the results of giving reluctantly.
What are the results of indulging in excessive sensual pleasures?
What happened to a prince that committed evil actions towards a Pacceka Buddha?
What happens when you associate with evil monks?
A ghost explains the results of associating with an evil monk.
Arahant Moggallana talks with ghosts who suffer due to their stinginess in the human world.
A woman and a ghost discuss doing meritorious deeds to avoid bad destinations.
What happens when you share merits with your past relatives?
What was the result of giving a small gift?
What happens when you earn money in bad ways?
Ghosts discuss their past about not practicing generosity.
Arahant Moggallana asks a ghost about his past evil actions.

sc_eng_sutta: Sumanā, Who Went Forth Late in Life
To Abhayā’s Mother From Her Daughter
Paṭācārā, Who Had a Following of Five Hundred
The Conduct of One Who Provided for His Mother

sc_blurb: This discourse regarding Truth was delivered by the Blessed One, while he was dwelling in the Great Monastery at Jetavana near Savatthi. But who, you ask, was it that led up to this tale?

sc_eng_sutta: Sandy Waste: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Untiring, deep they dug.”—This discourse was delivered by the Blessed One whilst he was dwelling at Savatthi.

sc_eng_sutta: The Wanton Merchant: a past life story
sc_blurb: “If in this faith.” This lesson too was taught by the Blessed One while at Savatthi, also about a Brother who gave up persevering.

sc_eng_sutta: The Little Financier: a past life story
sc_blurb: “With humblest start.” This story was told by the Master about the Elder named Little Wayman, while in Jivaka’s Mango-grove near Rajagaha.

sc_eng_sutta: A Cup of Rice: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Dost ask how much a peck of rice is worth?”—This was told by the Master, whilst at Jetavana, about the Elder Udayi, called the Dullard.

sc_eng_sutta: Godly Qualities: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Those only ‘godlike’ call.”—This story was told by the Blessed One while at Jetavana, about a wealthy Brother.

sc_eng_sutta: The Wood Gatherer: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Your son am I.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the story of Vasabha-Khattiya, which will be found in the Twelfth Book in the Bhaddasala-jataka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Chief: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Their heart’s desire.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a Brother who gave up persevering. In this Jataka both the Introductory Story and the Story of the Past will be given in the Eleventh Book in connexion with the Samvara-jataka; the incidents are the same both for that Jataka and for this, but the stanzas are different.
“Lo! these grey hairs.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the Great Renunciation, which has already been related in the Nidana-Katha.

sc_eng_sutta: Living at Ease: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The man who guards not.”—This story was told by the Master while in the Anupiya Mango-grove near the town of Anupiya, about the Elder Bhaddiya (the Happy), who joined the Brotherhood in the company of the six young nobles with whom was Upali. Of these the Elders Bhaddiya, Kimbila, Bhagu, and Upali attained to Arahatship; the Elder Ananda entered the First Path; the Elder Anuruddha gained all-seeing vision; and Devadatta obtained the power of ecstatic self-abstraction. The story of the six young nobles, up to the events at Anupiya, will be related in the Khandahala-jataka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Deer Named Lucky Spot: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The upright man.”—This story was told by the Master in the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha about Devadatta. The story of Devadatta will be related, up to the date of the Abhimara-employment, in the Khandahala-jataka; up to the date of his dismissal from the office of Treasurer, in the Cullahamsa-jataka; and, up to the date of his being swallowed up by the earth, in the Sixteenth Book in the Samudda-vanija-jataka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Deer Named Banyan: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Keep only with the Banyan Deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the mother of the Elder named Prince Kassapa. The daughter, we learn, of a wealthy merchant of Rajagaha was deeply rooted in goodness and scorned all temporal things; she had reached her final existence, and within her breast, like a lamp in a pitcher, glowed her sure hope of winning Arahatship. As soon as she reached knowledge of herself, she took no joy in a worldly life but yearned to renounce the world. With this aim, she said to her mother and father, “My dear parents, my heart takes no joy in a worldly life; fain would I embrace the saving doctrine of the Buddha. Suffer me to take the vows.”

sc_eng_sutta: The Arrow: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Cursed be the dart of love.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the temptation caused to Brethren by the wives of their mundane life. This will be related in the Indriya-jataka in the Eighth Book. Said the Blessed One to the Brother, “Brother, it was because of this very woman that in bygone days you met your death and were roasted over glowing embers.” The Brethren asked the Blessed One to explain this. The Blessed One made clear what had been concealed from them by re-birth.

sc_eng_sutta: The Wind-deer: a past life story
sc_blurb: “There’s nothing worse.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Tissa, called Direct-alms the Less. Tradition says that, while the Master was dwelling at the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha, the scion of a wealthy house, Prince Tissa by name, coming one day to the Bamboo-grove and there hearing a discourse from the Master, wished to join the Brotherhood, but, being refused because his parents would not give their consent, obtained their consent by following Rattha-pala’s example and refusing food for seven days, and finally took the vows with the Master.

sc_eng_sutta: Accept the Ass: a past life story
sc_blurb: “For when a deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about an unruly Brother. Tradition says that this Brother was unruly and would not heed admonition. Accordingly, the Master asked him, saying, “Is it true, as they say, that you are unruly and will not heed admonition?”

sc_eng_sutta: The Triply Collapsed Deer: a past life story
sc_blurb: “In all three postures.”—This story was told by the Master while dwelling do the Badarika Monastery in Kosambi, about the Elder Rahula whose heart was set on observing the rules of the Brotherhood.

“In light or dark.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about two Brethren who had joined the Brotherhood in their old age. Tradition says that they were living in a forest-dwelling in the Kosala country, and that one was named the Elder Dark and the other the Elder Light. Now one day Light said to Dark, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the dark half of the month.” And one day Dark said to Light, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the light half of the month.”

sc_eng_sutta: The Feast for the Dead: a past life story
sc_blurb: “If folk but knew.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about Feasts for the Dead. For at this time the folk were putting to death goats, sheep, and other animals, and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead, for the sake of their departed kinsmen. Finding them thus engaged, the Brethren asked the Master, saying, “Just now, sir, the folk are taking the lives of many living creatures and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead. Can it be, sir, that there is any good in this?”

sc_eng_sutta: The Vowed Feast: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Take thought of life hereafter.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the offering of a sacrifice under vow to gods. Tradition says that in those days folk when going a journey on business, used to slay living creatures and offer them as a sacrifice to gods, and set out on their way, after making this vow,—“If we come safely back with a profit, we will give you another sacrifice.” And when they did come safely back with a profit, the Idea that this was all due to gods made them slay a number of living creatures and offer them up as a sacrifice to obtain a release from their vow.

sc_eng_sutta: The Reed Drink: a past life story
sc_blurb: “I found the footprints.” This story was told by the Master whilst journeying on an alms-pilgrimage through Kosala, when he had come to the village of Nalaka-pana (Cane-drink) and was dwelling at Ketaka-vana near the Pool of Nalaka-pana, about cane-sticks. In those days the Brethren, after bathing in the Pool of Nalaka-pana, made the novices get them cane-sticks for needle-cases, but, finding them hollow throughout, went to the Master and said, “Sir, we had cane-sticks got in order to provide needle-cases; and from top to bottom they are quite hollow. Now how can that be?”

sc_eng_sutta: The Four-horned Antelope: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The antelope knows well.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about Devadatta. For once when the Brethren were gathered together in the Hall of Truth, they sat talking reproachfully of Devadatta, saying, “Sirs, with a view to destroy the Buddha Devadatta hired bowmen, hurled down a rock, and let loose the elephant Dhana-palaka; in every way he goes about to slay the Lord of Wisdom.” Entering and seating himself on the seat prepared for him, the Master asked, saying, “Sirs, what is the theme you are discussing here in conclave?” “Sir,” was the reply, “we were discussing the wickedness of Devadatta, saying that he was always going about to slay you.” Said the Master, “It is not only in these present days, Brethren, that Devadatta goes about seeking to slay me; he went about with the like intent in bygone days also,—but was unable to slay me.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.

“The dogs that in the royal palace grow.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about acting for the good of kinsfolk, as will be related in the Twelfth Book in the Bhaddasala-jataka. It was to drive home that lesson that he told this story of the past.

“Though prostrate now.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a Brother who gave up persevering. For it was then that the Master addressed that Brother and said, “Brethren, in bygone days the wise and good persevered even amid hostile surroundings, and, even when they were wounded, still did not give in.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.

sc_eng_sutta: The Thoroughbred: a past life story
sc_blurb: “No matter when or where.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about another Brother who gave up persevering. But, in this case, he addressed that Brother and said, “Brethren, in bygone days the wise and good still persevered even when wounded.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.
“Change thou the spot.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about an ex-goldsmith, who had become a Brother and was co-resident with the Captain of the Faith (Sariputta).

sc_eng_sutta: The Elephant Named Ladyface: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Through hearing first.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta, who, having secured the adherence of Prince Ajata-sattu, had attained both gain and honour. Prince Ajata-sattu had a Monastery built for Devadatta at Gaya-sisa, and every day brought to him five hundred kettles of perfumed three-year-old rice flavoured with all the choicest flavourings. All this gain and honour brought Devadatta a great following, with whom Devadatta lived on, without ever stirring out of his Monastery.
“No morsel can he eat.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-disciple and an aged Elder.

sc_eng_sutta: The Ox Named Nandivisāla: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Speak only words of kindness.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the bitter words spoken by the Six. For, in those days the six, when they disagreed with respectable Brethren, used to taunt, revile and jeer them, and load them with the ten kinds of abuse. This the Brethren reported to the Blessed One, who sent for the Six and asked whether this charge was true. On their admitting its truth, he rebuked them, saying, “Brethren, hard words gall even animals: in bygone days an animal made a man who had used harsh language to him lose a thousand pieces.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.

sc_eng_sutta: The Ox Named Black: a past life story
sc_blurb: “With heavy loads.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Double Miracle, which, together with the Descent from Heaven, will be related in the Thirteenth Book, in the Sarabhamiga-jataka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Pig Named Munika: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Then envy not poor Munika.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about being seduced by a plump young woman, as will be related in the Thirteenth Book in the Culla-Narada-Kassapa-jataka.
“Let all the forest’s nestlings.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a brother who drank water without straining it.
“A pleasing note.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother with many belongings. The incident is just the same as in the Devadhamma-jataka supra.
“While concord reigns.” This story was told by the Master while dwelling in the Banyan-grove near Kapilavatthu, about a squabble over a porter’s head-pad, as will be related in the Kunala-jataka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Fish: a past life story
sc_blurb: “’Tis not the cold.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about being seduced by the wife of one’s mundane life before joining the Brotherhood. Said the Master on this occasion, “Is it true, as I hear, Brother, that you are passion-tost?”

sc_eng_sutta: The Quail: a past life story
sc_blurb: “With, wings that fly not.”—This story was told by the Master, whilst on an alms-pilgrimage through Magadha, about the going-out of a jungle fire.
“Ye denizens of air.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother whose cell was burnt down.

sc_eng_sutta: The Partridge: a past life story
sc_blurb: “For they who honour age.”—This story was told by the Master whilst on his way to Savatthi, about the way in which the Elder Sariputta was kept out of a night’s lodging.

sc_eng_sutta: The Crane: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Guile profits not.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a tailoring Brother.
“Methinks the gold.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a co-resident pupil of Sariputta.

sc_eng_sutta: The Pit of Acacia Coals: a past life story
sc_blurb: “Far rather will I headlong plunge.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about Anatha-pindika.

sc_eng_sutta: About Losaka: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The headstrong man.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the Elder Losaka Tissa.

sc_eng_sutta: The Pigeon: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The headstrong man.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain greedy Brother. His greediness will be related in the Ninth Book in the Kaka Jātaka.

sc_eng_sutta: The Pole Acrobat: a past life story
sc_blurb: “The headstrong man.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain headstrong Brother. For the Blessed One asked him whether the report was true that he was headstrong, and the Brother admitted that it was. “Brother,” said the Master, “this is not the first time you have been headstrong: you were just as headstrong in former days. also, and, as the result of your headstrong refusal to follow the advice of the wise and good, you met your end by the bite of a snake.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.

sc_eng_sutta: The Mosquito: a past life story
